gst.name: Goods and Services Tax (GST) – Registration and Return Filing Compliance

applicability.condition: GST is a destination-based indirect tax on the supply of goods and services in India. It applies to all businesses (including SMEs and MSMEs) that are required to register under GST or that opt for voluntary registration. Once registered, a taxpayer must comply with periodic return filing (monthly/quarterly/annual) and payment requirements for all GST registrations (GSTINs) it holds across India.

threshold.details: Based on multiple 2025 guides (ClearTax, IndiaFilings, Razorpay, LegalWiz, Kladana) and official/industry publications: (a) For suppliers engaged exclusively in intra-State supply of goods in regular category States/UTs, GST registration is generally mandatory when aggregate turnover exceeds ₹40,00,000 (₹40 lakh). (b) For suppliers of goods located in special category States, the threshold is ₹20,00,000 (₹20 lakh) according to GST MSME and Kladana resources. (c) For suppliers of services in most States, the mandatory registration threshold is ₹20,00,000 (₹20 lakh) as reiterated by MarckenConsulting, ProAnalyser, Razorpay and others. (d) For service providers in special category States, Kladana explicitly notes a lower threshold of ₹10,00,000 (₹10 lakh). These thresholds are for aggregate turnover on an all‑India basis and can change by notification; users must cross‑check the current limits on the GST portal or from official GST Council notifications.

states: GST applies in all States and Union Territories of India that are part of the GST regime.

Registration thresholds differ for so‑called "special category" States. Multiple sources (GST MSME booklet, Kladana, Razorpay and GST Council flyer) confirm that special category States have lower limits – typically ₹20 lakh for goods (instead of ₹40 lakh) and ₹10 lakh for services. As of the general GST framework, special category States primarily comprise several North‑Eastern and hill States (e.g., Arunachal Pradesh, Manipur, Meghalaya, Mizoram, Nagaland, Sikkim, Tripura, Uttarakhand and others as notified). Because the precise notified list and limits have evolved over time, taxpayers should confirm the current special‑category classification and thresholds from the latest GST Council notifications or the GST portal.
exemptions: Businesses with aggregate annual turnover strictly below the applicable exemption threshold (e.g., below ₹40 lakh for goods or below ₹20 lakh for services in regular States; below ₹20 lakh/₹10 lakh in special category States as applicable) are generally not required to register under GST, as stated by IndiaFilings' GST exemption guide and GST MSME sector booklet.

Certain activities and supplies that are wholly exempt from GST or are non‑taxable (for example, specified health care, education, and certain agricultural activities) may not trigger registration solely because of such exempt supplies; however, mixed supplies and reverse charge obligations can alter this position and must be evaluated separately.

Registration is not mandatory solely due to turnover if a person engages exclusively in exempt supplies; however, if they engage in taxable supplies or fall under compulsory registration categories (e.g., e‑commerce operator, inter‑State supplier in certain categories, TDS/TCS deductor), they may need registration regardless of turnover.

IndiaFilings and other 2025 guides highlight that businesses may choose voluntary registration even below the threshold in order to claim input tax credit (ITC), to sell to B2B customers who require GST invoices, or to participate on e‑commerce platforms.

forms.name: GSTR-1 (Monthly) – Statement of Outward Supplies
forms.description: Monthly return for reporting details of outward supplies of goods and/or services (B2B, B2C, exports, deemed exports, credit/debit notes, advances, etc.) for regular registered taxpayers. This form is generally required for taxpayers whose aggregate turnover exceeds ₹5 crore in the preceding financial year or for those who voluntarily opt out of the quarterly QRMP scheme. The ClearTax dedicated GSTR-1 page for 2025 specifically shows a schedule for taxpayers with more than ₹5 crore turnover, confirming monthly filing with due dates on the 11th of the following month (Jan 2025 – 11 Feb 2025; Feb 2025 – 11 Mar 2025; Mar 2025 – 11 Apr 2025; Apr 2025 – 11 May 2025).

deadline.formula: 11th day of the month immediately following the tax period (month) for which outward supplies are being reported.
deadline.calculation: 1) Identify the tax period (e.g., January 2025). 2) Move to the next calendar month (February 2025). 3) The standard due date is the 11th of that following month. Example from ClearTax GSTR-1 schedule: For supplies made in Jan 2025, GSTR-1 must be filed by 11 Feb 2025; for Feb 2025, the due date is 11 Mar 2025; for Mar 2025, 11 Apr 2025; for Apr 2025, 11 May 2025. 4) If the 11th falls on a weekend/holiday, the due date normally remains unchanged unless a specific government notification extends it for that period.
deadline.gracePeriod: There is no automatic statutory grace period; late fees start accruing from the day after the due date. Any relaxation occurs only through specific government notifications.
deadline.extensions: Multiple 2025 compliance calendars (ClearTax GST Calendar 2025–26 and IndiaFilings) record specific extensions: for returns due in January 2025, the due date for monthly GSTR-1 was extended from 11 January 2025 to 13 January 2025. These extensions are period-specific and must be tracked each month via official CBIC/GST portal notifications or reliable GST calendars.

forms.penalty: According to 2025 penalty guides from DMI Finance, Razorpay and TCS iON, late filing of GSTR-1 attracts: (a) a late fee of ₹50 per day of delay for returns that are not Nil (₹25 under CGST + ₹25 under SGST/UTGST), and (b) a reduced late fee of ₹20 per day for Nil returns (₹10 CGST + ₹10 SGST/UTGST). These guides state a cap of ₹5,000 on the late fee per return. Open.money illustrates this with an example: a Nil return delayed by 10 days results in a late fee of ₹200 (₹20 × 10 days). In addition, interest at 18% per annum is levied on any tax liability paid after the due date (ClearTax and SSCO India), calculated on the unpaid tax from the day after the due date until the date of payment using the formula: Interest = Tax due × 18% × (Number of days of delay ÷ 365). Wrongful or excess input tax credit (ITC) claims, or excess reduction in output tax liability, draw a higher interest rate of 24% per annum (SSCO India and ClearTax). Further, a Taxtmi discussion notes that some State authorities have imposed a general penalty under Section 125 of the CGST/SGST Acts of up to ₹50,000 (₹25,000 CGST + ₹25,000 SGST) for delays (they specifically mention GSTR-3B but the same section can apply to general GST contraventions), so persistent or serious non‑compliance with GSTR-1 obligations can attract such discretionary penalties in addition to late fees and interest.

forms.name: GSTR-1 (Quarterly – QRMP/Small Taxpayer Filing) – Statement of Outward Supplies
forms.description: Quarterly GSTR-1 filing is intended for smaller taxpayers who opt into a quarterly return scheme. Under the modern QRMP (Quarterly Return Monthly Payment) framework, it is generally available to taxpayers with aggregate turnover up to ₹5 crore in the preceding financial year, although one 2025 calendar from SAG Infotech still refers to an older threshold of ₹1.5 crore for quarterly GSTR-1 filing. In quarterly GSTR-1, outward supplies for the entire quarter (three calendar months) are declared together. To facilitate B2B recipients’ ITC during the quarter, such taxpayers may optionally use the Invoice Furnishing Facility (IFF) in the first two months of the quarter.

deadline.formula: 13th day of the month immediately following the end of the relevant quarter.
deadline.calculation: 1) Determine the quarter: Q4 (Jan–Mar), Q1 (Apr–Jun), Q2 (Jul–Sep), Q3 (Oct–Dec). 2) Identify the month following the quarter end. 3) The standard due date is the 13th of that following month. SAG Infotech's 2025 due-date table (for turnover up to ₹1.5 crore) illustrates this: Jan–Mar 2025 quarter – due 13 April 2025; Apr–Jun 2025 quarter – due 13 July 2025; Jul–Sep 2025 quarter – due 13 October 2025. 4) Delhi Trade & Tax department's 2024 calendar similarly lists GSTR-1 (Jul–Sep) due on 13 October 2024, consistent with a '13th of the month after the quarter' rule.
deadline.gracePeriod: No automatic grace period exists; the due date is hard unless extended by notification. Late fee accrues from the day after the due date.
deadline.extensions: IndiaFilings' update on due date extensions notes that for the tax period whose GSTR-1 was due in January 2025, the quarterly GSTR-1 due date was extended to 15 January 2025 (from the usual 13th). Such quarter‑specific extensions must be monitored each period on the GST portal or via official notifications.

forms.penalty: The late fee structure for quarterly GSTR-1 is the same as for monthly GSTR-1: ₹50 per day for returns with any tax or data (₹25 CGST + ₹25 SGST/UTGST) and ₹20 per day for Nil returns (₹10 + ₹10), with multiple 2025 guides indicating a maximum of ₹5,000 per return. Interest at 18% per annum applies on any tax paid late, and 24% per annum on wrongful or excess ITC claims. The Open.money example (Nil return delayed by 10 days giving ₹200 late fee) globally illustrates the calculation. General penalty under Section 125 (up to ₹50,000 for CGST+SGST together) may also be invoked for material non‑compliance, though this is not automatic and depends on the tax authority’s discretion.

forms.name: GSTR-3B (Monthly) – Summary Return and Tax Payment
forms.description: GSTR-3B is a self-declared summary return used for reporting summary details of outward supplies, inward supplies on which tax is payable under reverse charge, eligible and ineligible input tax credit, and the final tax payable along with tax payment. It is filed monthly by regular taxpayers, particularly those with aggregate turnover exceeding ₹5 crore or any registered person who has not opted for the QRMP scheme. Rajendra & Co’s GST due dates for 2025 and DMI Finance's GST return due dates guide confirm that for taxpayers with turnover exceeding ₹5 crore, GSTR-1 is due on the 11th and GSTR-3B on the 20th of each month.

deadline.formula: 20th day of the month immediately following the tax period (month) for which GST liability is being discharged.
deadline.calculation: 1) Identify the tax period month (e.g., July 2024 or January 2025). 2) Move to the next month. 3) The standard due date for GSTR-3B is the 20th of that following month. For example, as shown on the Delhi Trade & Tax department’s "Upcoming Due Dates" page, GSTR-3B for July 2024 is due on 20 August 2024. Rajendra & Co’s 2025 PDF states in general that for those with turnover exceeding ₹5 crore, GSTR-3B is due on the 20th of each month.
deadline.gracePeriod: There is no automatic grace period; late fee and interest count from the 21st of the month (or the next day after any extended due date).
deadline.extensions: IndiaFilings’ article on GSTR-1 and GSTR-3B due date extensions records that for the period whose GSTR-3B was normally due in January 2025, the monthly GSTR-3B due date was extended to 22 January 2025 (instead of 20 January 2025). Extensions of this kind are effected via government notifications and apply for specific tax periods only.

forms.penalty: All 2025 penalty guides (Razorpay, DMI Finance, TCS iON, SSCO India) indicate that late filing of GSTR-3B attracts a late fee of ₹50 per day (₹25 CGST + ₹25 SGST/UTGST) for returns that are not Nil, and ₹20 per day (₹10 CGST + ₹10 SGST/UTGST) for Nil returns, with a cap of ₹5,000 per return commonly cited. Interest of 18% per annum is payable on any net tax liability that is paid after the due date, calculated as: Interest = Net tax payable × 18% × (Number of days of delay ÷ 365). For any excess or wrongful ITC claims reversed later, interest is 24% per annum as highlighted by SSCO India and ClearTax. Additionally, a Taxtmi forum note reports that in many States, authorities have invoked Section 125 to levy a general penalty of ₹50,000 (₹25,000 CGST + ₹25,000 SGST) even for a one-day delay in filing GSTR-3B, illustrating that GSTR-3B is particularly scrutinised and that general penalties can be significant in addition to standard late fees and interest.

forms.name: GSTR-3B (Quarterly – QRMP) – Summary Return and Tax Payment
forms.description: Under the QRMP (Quarterly Return Monthly Payment) scheme, eligible small taxpayers (generally those with aggregate turnover up to ₹5 crore in the preceding financial year) may file GSTR-3B on a quarterly basis instead of monthly, while paying tax monthly using a fixed sum or self-assessment method. The GST Portal’s official FAQ on Form GSTR-3B specifies that for quarterly filers, the due date is notified separately for different States/UTs.

deadline.formula: 22nd or 24th day of the month following the end of the relevant quarter, depending on the State/UT group as notified.
deadline.calculation: 1) Identify the quarter (e.g., Jul–Sep 2024, Jan–Mar 2025). 2) Move to the month immediately following the quarter end (e.g., October 2024 for Jul–Sep 2024). 3) Based on the State/UT in which the principal place of business is located, read the notification or the GST Portal FAQ to know whether the due date is the 22nd or the 24th of that month. The Delhi Trade & Tax department’s upcoming due dates table for GSTR-3B (Jul–Sep) 2024 lists two due dates: 22 October 2024 and 24 October 2024, reflecting the two State groups described by the GST portal FAQ. 4) For example, for a taxpayer in a State falling in the "22nd" group, GSTR-3B for the Jul–Sep 2024 quarter is due on 22 October 2024; for a taxpayer in a "24th" group State, it is due on 24 October 2024.
deadline.gracePeriod: No automatic grace period is provided. Once the quarter-specific due date (22nd or 24th) is crossed, late fees and interest apply until filing and payment are completed.
deadline.extensions: The GST portal FAQ mentions only general rules, but IndiaFilings’ due date extension article records that, for one period whose return fell due in January 2025, quarterly GSTR-3B due dates were extended to 24 January 2025 and 26 January 2025 (instead of the usual 22nd and 24th) depending on the State group. Such extensions are ad‑hoc and must be confirmed from the relevant CBIC notifications for each quarter.

forms.penalty: The late fee and interest regime for quarterly GSTR-3B is the same as for monthly GSTR-3B: ₹50 per day of delay (₹25 CGST + ₹25 SGST/UTGST) for non‑Nil returns and ₹20 per day (₹10 + ₹10) for Nil returns, with various 2025 resources stating a cap of ₹5,000 per return. Interest is 18% per annum on delayed payment of tax and 24% per annum on wrongful ITC claims. As noted by SSCO India, a common non‑compliance is not paying interest on delayed tax separately, which can lead to additional notices. General penalty under Section 125 (up to ₹50,000 for CGST+SGST combined) can also be applied for continued failure or other breaches around quarterly 3B filing and payment.

forms.name: GSTR-7 – Return for Tax Deducted at Source (TDS)
forms.description: GSTR-7 is the monthly return filed by persons required to deduct tax at source (TDS) under GST, such as certain government departments, local authorities, agencies, and specified categories of notified deductors. It reports details of TDS deducted, TDS liability, TDS paid, and any TDS refunded for each deductee GSTIN.

deadline.formula: 10th day of the month following the tax period for which TDS is deducted, unless extended by notification.
deadline.calculation: GimBooks’ December 2025 GST filing calendar specifies that for December 2025, GSTR-7 is due on 10 December (this refers to the November 2025 tax period, due in December). The general pattern is: 1) Identify the month in which TDS is deducted (e.g., November 2025). 2) The due date for filing GSTR-7 reporting that TDS is the 10th of the following month (10 December 2025).
deadline.gracePeriod: No automatic grace period is provided in law; late fee and interest begin from 11th of the following month (or from the day after any officially extended due date).
deadline.extensions: The ClearTax GST Calendar 2025–26 shows that for returns due in January 2025, the due date for both GSTR-7 and GSTR-8 was extended from the usual 10 January to 12 January 2025. Such extensions are specific to the notified period and must be checked for each month.

forms.penalty: Late filing of GSTR-7 is subject to the standard GST late fee regime: guidance from Razorpay, DMI Finance, TCS iON and Open.money indicates a late fee of ₹50 per day (₹25 CGST + ₹25 SGST/UTGST) for non‑Nil returns and ₹20 per day (₹10 + ₹10) for Nil returns, capped at ₹5,000 per return. In addition, if deducted tax is not deposited to the government by the due date, interest at 18% per annum applies on the unpaid TDS amount from the date on which tax was deductible to the date of actual payment. Wrongful or under‑reported TDS adjustments that create an ITC issue for deductees may also be viewed as non‑compliance. As with other returns, general penalties under Section 125 (up to ₹25,000 under CGST and a matching amount under SGST) can be imposed for serious TDS‑related non‑compliance.

forms.name: GSTR-8 – Return for Tax Collected at Source (TCS) by E-commerce Operators
forms.description: GSTR-8 is the monthly return filed by e-commerce operators who are required to collect tax at source (TCS) on supplies made through their platform by other suppliers. It contains details of supplies made, the amount collected as TCS, and the TCS liability payable.

deadline.formula: 10th day of the month following the tax period during which TCS is collected, subject to notified extensions.
deadline.calculation: As per GimBooks’ GST filing dates for December 2025, GSTR-8 is due on 10 December 2025, aligning with GSTR-7. The generic process is: 1) Identify the month in which TCS is collected (e.g., November 2025). 2) The return reporting that collection is due on the 10th of the subsequent month (10 December 2025).
deadline.gracePeriod: No statutory grace period; late fee applies from the day after the due date.
deadline.extensions: ClearTax’s GST Calendar 2025–26 shows that for a particular extended period (returns due in January 2025), the GSTR-7 and GSTR-8 due date was extended from 10 January 2025 to 12 January 2025.

forms.penalty: Late filing of GSTR-8 attracts the same standard late fee detailed in 2025 penalty guides: ₹50 per day (₹25 CGST + ₹25 SGST/UTGST) for normal returns and ₹20 per day (₹10 + ₹10) for Nil returns, capped at ₹5,000 per return. Interest at 18% per annum is charged on any TCS amount not deposited by the due date. Additionally, failure to correctly collect or report TCS can lead to penalties under Section 122 (for incorrect invoices/under‑reporting) and general penalties under Section 125 (up to ₹25,000 per Act) at the discretion of the authorities.

forms.name: GSTR-6 – Return for Input Service Distributors (ISD)
forms.description: GSTR-6 is the monthly return filed by Input Service Distributors (ISDs) who receive input services and distribute the eligible input tax credit (ITC) to their branches or units having distinct GST registrations. It contains details of input services received, ITC availed, and ITC distributed.

deadline.formula: 13th day of the month following the tax period for which ITC is being distributed.
deadline.calculation: GimBooks’ December 2025 calendar lists 13 December 2025 as the due date for GSTR-5, GSTR-6 and IFF. ClearTax’s GST calendar similarly groups GSTR-5 and GSTR-6 around 13 January 2025 in the context of extensions. The standard rule, confirmed by multiple GST calendars, is that GSTR-6 is due on the 13th day of the month following the relevant tax period. For example, ISD credits for November 2025 must ordinarily be reported by 13 December 2025.
deadline.gracePeriod: No automatic grace period; late fee accrues starting from the 14th of the month (or the day after any extended due date).
deadline.extensions: The ClearTax GST calendar notes that for tax periods whose returns were due in January 2025, the due date for GSTR-6 (grouped with GSTR-5 and possibly IFF) was extended to 13 January 2025, implying a notified relaxation for that month. All such changes are period-specific and must be validated with the latest CBIC circulars.

forms.penalty: Standard GST late fee rules (₹50 per day for non‑Nil, ₹20 per day for Nil, capped at ₹5,000) apply to delayed GSTR-6 filings as summarized by Razorpay, DMI Finance and TCS iON. Interest at 18% per annum may apply where ITC distribution affects tax payment timings (for example, when redistribution leads to short payment in a recipient unit). Wrongful or excessive ITC distribution can be treated as wrongful ITC claim, attracting 24% per annum interest on the excess amount until corrected, as indicated by SSCO India and ClearTax. General penalties under Section 122 or 125 may apply to incorrect or fraudulent distribution of ITC.

forms.name: GSTR-5 – Return for Non-Resident Taxable Persons (NRTP)
forms.description: GSTR-5 is the return to be filed by non-resident taxable persons (NRTPs) who occasionally undertake transactions in India but do not have a fixed place of business in India. It reports details of outward supplies, inward supplies, ITC (if any), and tax payment for the period of registration.

deadline.formula: Statutorily, GSTR-5 is generally due by the 20th of the month following the tax period or within 7 days after the expiry of the registration, whichever is earlier. However, some 2025 compliance calendars present it around the 13th alongside GSTR-6.
deadline.calculation: 1) Most statutory summaries indicate that for an NRTP whose registration is valid beyond a given month, GSTR-5 for that month is due by the 20th of the next month (e.g., for supplies in November 2025, by 20 December 2025). 2) If the registration expires earlier, the final GSTR-5 is due within 7 days of expiry. 3) In practice, GimBooks and ClearTax 2025 GST calendars group GSTR-5 and GSTR-6 on 13 December 2025 and 13 January 2025 respectively; these may reflect specific notifications or local interpretations for some periods. Therefore, NRTPs should always confirm the exact due date for their registration period on the GST portal.
deadline.gracePeriod: No automatic grace period. Any relaxation in the 20th/7-days-after-expiry rule comes only through explicit notifications extending due dates for specific periods.
deadline.extensions: ClearTax’s GST Calendar 2025–26 and GimBooks' December 2025 due date article list GSTR-5 with GSTR-6 and IFF on or around the 13th of the month (e.g., 13 December 2025 and 13 January 2025), suggesting that some periods enjoyed special extensions or alternate due dates; filers must rely on the GST portal or CBIC notifications for confirmation.

forms.penalty: Late filing of GSTR-5 results in: (a) the standard late fee of ₹50 per day (₹25 CGST + ₹25 SGST/UTGST) or ₹20 per day for Nil returns (₹10 + ₹10), capped at ₹5,000 per return as per the 2025 penalty guides; and (b) interest at 18% per annum on any tax amount payable but paid late. Since NRTPs are often under close scrutiny, non‑compliance can additionally trigger penalties under Sections 122 and 125, including higher monetary penalties and potential blocking of refunds or future registrations.

forms.name: Invoice Furnishing Facility (IFF) – Optional Monthly B2B Invoice Upload for QRMP Taxpayers
forms.description: IFF is not a separate tax return but an optional facility available to taxpayers under the QRMP scheme to furnish B2B invoice details for the first two months of a quarter. It enables timely reflection of invoices in recipients’ GSTR-2B and allows them to claim ITC earlier, even though the supplier files GSTR-1 on a quarterly basis.

deadline.formula: 13th day of the month following the first and second months of each quarter for which the invoice details are being furnished.
deadline.calculation: GimBooks’ December 2025 GST due date article explicitly mentions that on 13 December 2025, GSTR-5, GSTR-6 and IFF are due, indicating that IFF for November 2025 (the second month of the Oct–Dec 2025 quarter) must be filed by 13 December 2025. In general: 1) For the first month of a quarter (e.g., October), IFF for that month is due by 13 November. 2) For the second month (e.g., November), IFF is due by 13 December. 3) No IFF is available for the third month; those invoices are reported directly in the quarterly GSTR-1 filed by the 13th of the month following the quarter.
deadline.gracePeriod: No separate grace period; if IFF is not filed in time, invoices can still be reported in the quarterly GSTR-1, but recipients’ ITC will be delayed.
deadline.extensions: GimBooks and ClearTax calendars that show specific dates like 13 December 2025 and 13 January 2025 effectively confirm standard IFF deadlines for those months. Any official extension would usually be communicated with the quarterly GSTR-1/GSTR-3B extensions.

forms.penalty: IFF is a facility within GSTR-1 rather than a mandated separate return; late or non‑use of IFF by itself does not attract a distinct late fee. However, if invoices are not ultimately reported in the quarterly GSTR-1 by its due date, the standard GSTR-1 late fee (₹50/₹20 per day with cap of ₹5,000) and interest implications for recipient-side mismatches may arise. Delays in providing invoice data can also create commercial friction as buyers may withhold payment or consider the compliance risk.

forms.name: GSTR-9 – Annual Return
forms.description: GSTR-9 is the annual return consolidating the information furnished in monthly/quarterly returns (such as GSTR-1 and GSTR-3B) for a financial year. It includes detailed break-up of outward and inward supplies, ITC availed and reversed, demands and refunds, and other adjustments. The SAG Infotech blog referenced in the search results covers due dates for GSTR-1, GSTR-3B up to GSTR-9 and GSTR-9C, indicating its continued relevance for 2025. Certain small taxpayers below specified turnover thresholds may be exempt from filing GSTR-9 for particular financial years, subject to government notifications.

deadline.formula: Typically, 31 December of the year following the end of the relevant financial year, unless extended by notification.
deadline.calculation: For a financial year ending on 31 March 2025 (FY 2024–25), the statutory due date under the CGST Rules is generally 31 December 2025, unless the Government notifies an extension. Historically, the due date has often been extended via notifications. The SAG Infotech article (covering return due dates up to GSTR-9 and 9C) would normally list that 31 December deadline and any extended dates, though these details are not fully visible in the snippet and must be verified from the current financial year’s notification.
deadline.gracePeriod: No formal grace period; once the notified due/extended date passes, late fees are triggered. However, the Government frequently extends the due date for GSTR-9 by issuing late notifications, which operate as de facto grace periods.
deadline.extensions: For 2025, the search snippet does not show explicit GSTR-9 extensions, but prior years consistently saw extensions announced late in the calendar year. Taxpayers should monitor CBIC/GST Council notifications and SAG Infotech or similar updated calendars for FY 2024–25 and later.

forms.penalty: Late filing of GSTR-9 attracts a late fee similar in structure to periodic returns, though different caps can apply by notification. Multiple 2025 penalty summaries (Razorpay, TCS iON, ClearTax) describe a general per‑day late fee regime of ₹50 per day (₹25 CGST + ₹25 SGST) and ₹20 per day for Nil returns, with a maximum of ₹5,000 per return; however, for annual returns, the cap has sometimes been higher (per the CGST Act and specific notifications) and may differ by financial year. Interest at 18% per annum is payable on any additional tax liability declared in GSTR-9 that is paid after the original due date for the relevant GSTR-3B periods. Wrongful ITC admissions uncovered in the annual reconciliation may also trigger 24% per annum interest on excess ITC. General penalties under Sections 122 and 125 may be imposed for significant discrepancies or non‑filing.

forms.name: GSTR-9C – Reconciliation Statement / Audit Certification
forms.description: GSTR-9C is a reconciliation statement between the figures declared in GSTR-9 and the audited financial statements, certified by a Chartered Accountant or Cost Accountant where required. The SAG Infotech due date article explicitly mentions GSTR-9 and GSTR-9C in its scope for 2025, reflecting that the form remains relevant for taxpayers above the prescribed audit threshold.

deadline.formula: Ordinarily, the due date for GSTR-9C is aligned with the due date for GSTR-9, typically 31 December of the year following the end of the relevant financial year, unless otherwise extended.
deadline.calculation: For FY 2024–25 (ending 31 March 2025), the due date for GSTR-9C would typically be 31 December 2025, mirroring GSTR-9’s deadline, subject to changes via notification. Historically, the GSTR-9C deadline has often been extended in tandem with GSTR-9, and SAG Infotech’s 2025 due date article would normally indicate any such revised dates.
deadline.gracePeriod: No grace period beyond any officially extended deadline. Non‑filing or late filing beyond the extended date can attract penalties and jeopardize the validity of annual filings.
deadline.extensions: The 2025 search snippets do not show explicit extended dates for GSTR-9C, but given previous patterns, any extension announced for GSTR-9 is commonly mirrored for GSTR-9C. Final dates must be checked in CBIC notifications applicable to the relevant financial year.

forms.penalty: There is no separate late fee specified in the snippets for GSTR-9C, but failure to furnish a required reconciliation statement can be considered non‑compliance with Section 44 read with Section 35 of the CGST Act, and can attract penalties under Section 125 (general penalty up to ₹25,000 under CGST and a matching amount under SGST) and potentially Section 122 if it leads to tax short‑payment or incorrect reporting. Any additional tax liability emerging from reconciliation and paid late will draw 18% per annum interest, and wrongful ITC identified through the audit may attract 24% per annum interest on the excess ITC until reversal and payment.

additionalInfo.registration: Multiple 2025 resources (ClearTax's GST registration limits, IndiaFilings, ProAnalyser, LegalWiz, Kladana, GST MSME booklet and the GST Council flyer) collectively confirm that: (a) For suppliers exclusively dealing in goods in regular category States, GST registration is mandatory once the aggregate turnover exceeds ₹40,00,000 (₹40 lakh). (b) For suppliers of goods in special category States, the exemption threshold is about ₹20,00,000 (₹20 lakh). (c) For suppliers of services across India, the base threshold is ₹20,00,000 (₹20 lakh), while service providers in special category States have a lower threshold of ₹10,00,000 (₹10 lakh) per the Kladana 2025 guide. Aggregation is on an all‑India basis across all business verticals having the same PAN. When the applicable threshold is crossed, registration is 'non-negotiable' as explicitly stated in the LegalWiz MSME GST compliance checklist. Voluntary registration is permitted even below the threshold, in which case all return filing and payment obligations fully apply. Certain categories (e.g., certain e‑commerce operators, persons required to deduct/collect TDS/TCS, inter‑State suppliers in defined categories) must register irrespective of turnover, although these details are beyond what is shown in the search snippets and must be checked against the CGST Act and latest notifications.
additionalInfo.renewal: GST registration does not require periodic renewal; it remains valid until it is cancelled by the tax authorities or surrendered by the taxpayer. However, persistent non‑filing of returns (such as GSTR-3B) can result in suspension or cancellation of registration, after which reactivation or fresh registration would be required. While there is no formal renewal cycle for GST registrations, SMEs must maintain continuous compliance (filings and payments) to avoid such actions.
additionalInfo.filingMethod: All core GST returns (GSTR-1, GSTR-3B, GSTR-5, GSTR-6, GSTR-7, GSTR-8, GSTR-9, GSTR-9C, and IFF) are filed electronically via the common GST portal (www.gst.gov.in). The GST portal provides online forms and offline tools/utilities for data preparation and upload. Authentication is typically through Digital Signature Certificate (DSC) for companies/LLPs and through electronic verification code (EVC) options such as OTP for other entities. State portals like the Delhi Trade & Tax website mirror due dates but the actual filing is centralised on the GST portal. Payment of tax, interest, late fees and penalties is also effected online via the GST portal using internet banking, NEFT/RTGS, or OTC methods as permitted.
additionalInfo.prerequisites: Key prerequisites for GST compliance include: (a) Valid GST registration (GSTIN) linked to PAN, supported by KYC documentation and bank details. (b) Proper classification of goods and services with correct HSN/SAC codes to avoid penalties for incorrect invoice or HSN usage (TCS iON penalty guide mentions penalties for wrong HSN code). (c) A robust invoicing system aligned with GST invoicing rules (ProAnalyser’s 2025 compliance guide stresses compliant invoicing as a core requirement). (d) Maintenance of accurate books and records for outward supplies, inward supplies, ITC, and payments to support monthly/quarterly return data and the annual GSTR-9 and 9C reconciliation. (e) For QRMP taxpayers, internal processes to decide whether to use the fixed sum or self-assessment payment method and whether to use the IFF for the first two months of each quarter. (f) Reliable tracking of due dates and extensions, using updated calendars such as ClearTax’s GST calendar, DMI Finance's due date calendar, GimBooks’ monthly due date posts, and Delhi’s official due date page.
additionalInfo.recentUpdates: From the 2025-dated resources in the search results, notable compliance-related points include: (1) Registration thresholds remain widely communicated as ₹40 lakh for goods and ₹20 lakh for services in most States, with lower thresholds of ₹20 lakh (goods) and ₹10 lakh (services) for special category States (Kladana, Razorpay, ProAnalyser, GST MSME booklet). (2) Several 2025 articles reconfirm the mainstream return filing pattern: for monthly filers with turnover exceeding ₹5 crore, GSTR-1 is due on the 11th and GSTR-3B on the 20th of each month (Rajendra & Co, DMI Finance, Razorpay November 2025 guide). (3) The GST Portal FAQ (official) clarifies that for quarterly GSTR-3B filers, the due dates are the 22nd and 24th days of the month following the quarter, allocated to different groups of States/UTs, a pattern echoed in Delhi’s due date table. (4) Multiple 2025 GST calendars and IndiaFilings posts document specific due date extensions around January 2025: GSTR-7 and GSTR-8 extended to 12 January 2025; monthly GSTR-1 extended to 13 January 2025; quarterly GSTR-1 extended to 15 January 2025; monthly GSTR-3B extended to 22 January 2025; quarterly GSTR-3B extended to 24 and 26 January 2025 depending on State group. (5) GimBooks’ December 2025 article summarises that the key filing dates for that month are: 10 December for GSTR-7 and GSTR-8, 11 December for GSTR-1, 13 December for GSTR-5, GSTR-6 and IFF, and 20 December for major payment returns such as GSTR-3B. (6) The 2025 penalty guides (DMI Finance, TCS iON, Razorpay, Open.money, SSCO India, ClearTax) consistently present an aligned late fee structure: ₹50 per day (₹25+₹25) for non‑Nil returns, ₹20 per day (₹10+₹10) for Nil returns, with a cap of ₹5,000 per return, interest on delayed tax at 18% per annum, interest on wrongful ITC at 24% per annum, and interest on delayed refunds at 6% per annum when not granted within 60 days (Tax2win). (7) DMI Finance notes that from July 2025 there are additional developments affecting penalty computation for late filing (the snippet says, 'From July 2025, all taxpayers ...' but truncates the details), signalling that taxpayers should carefully review mid‑2025 updates in that guide and check corresponding official notifications for any revised caps or structures from that date. (8) A Taxtmi forum post from May 2025 highlights enforcement practice where GST authorities in many States levy a penalty of ₹50,000 under Section 125 for even a one‑day delay in GSTR-3B filing, underscoring a tightening of compliance enforcement. (9) Several 2025 MSME‑oriented guides (ProAnalyser, LegalWiz, Razorpay, Kladana) emphasise that GST compliance – including timely returns, accurate invoicing and ITC management – remains a critical regulatory focus area for SMEs, with no relaxation in core thresholds or fundamental obligations.

epf.name: Employees' Provident Fund (EPF) – Monthly Electronic Challan-cum-Return (ECR) Filing & Contribution Payment

applicability.condition: The Employees' Provident Fund (EPF) monthly Electronic Challan-cum-Return (ECR) filing and contribution payment requirement arises under the Employees' Provident Funds and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1952 and the EPF Scheme, 1952. Broadly, every factory or establishment in India that employs 20 or more persons in any industry or class of establishments notified by the Central Government is mandatorily covered. Once an establishment is covered, EPF coverage continues even if the employee strength later falls below 20, and the employer must file monthly ECR and pay contributions for all eligible employees. Establishments with fewer than 20 employees can voluntarily opt into EPF coverage by mutual agreement with their employees and by notification; once covered, they must also comply with monthly ECR filing. Guidance from Wisemonk (2025) reiterates that EPF contributions are mandatory for employers with 20+ employees, at 12% each from employer and employee, and that 2025 updates affect the earlier salary cap practice. EPF applies to all employees who fall within the statutory definition of 'employee' under the Act and are not specifically excluded (such as certain apprentices).
states: All States and Union Territories of India (EPF is a central legislation with uniform core provisions, contribution rates and federal penalties across India; there are no state-specific EPF contribution or penalty rates in the search results, and the 'state-specific' references in the penalty guidance relate to ESI, not EPF).
exemptions: Establishments employing fewer than 20 persons that have not opted for voluntary EPF coverage generally are not required to register under the EPF Act, unless specifically notified.

Exempted establishments (those that maintain their own recognised provident fund trusts under Section 17 of the EPF Act) may be exempt from the statutory EPF Scheme for fund management, but they remain subject to the Act and to EPFO oversight; their reporting and remittance obligations differ and may not use the standard ECR in the same way as non-exempt establishments.

Apprentices engaged under the Apprentices Act, 1961 or under standing orders of the establishment are excluded from EPF coverage and therefore do not attract EPF contributions or inclusion in the monthly ECR.

Employees who were earning above the prescribed wage ceiling at the time of joining historically were not mandatorily required to be enrolled in EPF, though they could be covered with consent; guidance in 2025 (Wisemonk) indicates that the earlier ₹15,000 salary cap practice for contributions has been removed for EPF contributions, but membership and EPS rules continue to be wage-based.

Certain categories of establishments (for example, those with fewer than 20 employees or in specific notified industries) are eligible for a reduced contribution rate of 10% (employer and employee each), as indicated in the EPFO 'Present Rates of Contribution' PDF; this is a concessional rate, not an exemption from coverage.

forms.name: Electronic Challan-cum-Return (ECR) – Monthly EPF/EPS/EDLI Return (legacy format up to wage month August 2025)
forms.description: The Electronic Challan-cum-Return (ECR) is the combined monthly return and challan used by employers covered under the EPF Act to declare employee-wise wages and statutory contributions and to generate a challan for remittance. It captures, for each employee, details such as Universal Account Number (UAN), wage month, EPF/EPS/EDLI wages, employee and employer contributions, and exit details where applicable. Up to wage month August 2025, employers used the existing ('legacy') ECR module on the EPFO employer portal to upload a text file or enter data online, generate the EPF challan, and pay contributions electronically. The ECR covers contributions towards Employees' Provident Fund (EPF), Employees' Pension Scheme (EPS) and Employees' Deposit-Linked Insurance (EDLI), plus administrative charges, as per rates published in the EPFO 'Present Rates of Contribution' PDF.

deadline.formula: The statutory due date for filing the ECR and remitting EPF, EPS and EDLI contributions is on or before the 15th day of the month immediately following the wage month. For example, contributions relating to wages for April 2025 are due in the month of May 2025, and must be paid with a filed ECR on or before 15 May 2025. This is consistent with standard EPF practice and is reflected indirectly in the EPFO ComplianceLetter_08102025 snippet referencing 'salary of April 2025, the due month for remittance of provident fund' and in due-date guidance materials.
deadline.calculation:
Step 1: Identify the wage month (e.g., April 2025).
Step 2: Move to the next calendar month (for April 2025, this is May 2025). This becomes the 'due month' for remittance.
Step 3: The statutory due date is the 15th day of that due month. For April 2025 wages, contributions must be remitted and the ECR must be filed on or before 15 May 2025.
Step 4: If the employer files and pays after the 15th, interest under Section 7Q and damages under Section 14B become applicable from the 16th day onward.
Example: For wage month June 2025, the due month is July 2025. The employer must upload the June 2025 ECR and complete payment on or before 15 July 2025. Payment and filing on 20 July 2025 would be 5 days late and attract interest under Section 7Q and damages under Section 14B from 16 July 2025 until the date of actual payment.
deadline.gracePeriod: As of 2025 there is no standard statutory grace period; interest under Section 7Q and damages under Section 14B apply from the day immediately following the statutory due date. Older guidance and historical practice that mentioned a short grace period have been superseded; the search results and the 2025 EPFO communications do not indicate any ongoing general grace period.
deadline.extensions: For the period covered by the legacy ECR (up to wage month August 2025), there is no routine extension of the 15th-of-next-month deadline. Any extensions are exceptional and would be notified via specific EPFO circulars or government press releases. The notable extension captured in the 2025 search results—extending the filing deadline to 22 October 2025—applies to the new, revamped ECR for wage month September 2025 and not to the earlier legacy ECR months.

forms.penalty:
If an employer does not complete the ECR filing and corresponding payment by the statutory due date (15th of the following month), two types of statutory financial consequences apply, in addition to potential prosecution for severe defaults:

1) Interest under Section 7Q of the EPF Act (for delay in payment):
- As stated in the EPFO ComplianceLetter_08102025, 'Interest under Section 7Q becomes automatically applicable (for delay in payment) and is computed by the system.'
- Guidance materials (Bajaj Finserv 'Provident Fund (PF) Due Dates in India & Late Payment ...', EPFO FAQ page, Wisemonk penalties FAQ) indicate that the statutory interest rate under Section 7Q is 12% per annum on the unpaid amount, calculated as simple interest from the date the contribution became due (the day after the due date, i.e., from the 16th of the following month) until the date of actual payment.
- The interest is automatically calculated by the EPFO system when the delayed payment is made; it is not discretionary and is payable in addition to any damages under Section 14B.
- Approximate daily rate: 12% per annum ≈ 12/365 ≈ 0.0329% per day on the outstanding amount.

2) Damages (penal charges) under Section 14B of the EPF Act (for default in payment):
- The EPFO FAQ (official) states that 'The employer shall be charged penal interest under section 7Q and penal damages under section 14B of the Act respectively.' These damages are a penalty intended to deter and punish late payment.
- Historical slab system (pre–14 June 2024): As per guidance sources such as ClearTax ('EPF Payment Online'), LabourLawAdvisor ('EPF Interest & Damages On Late Payment Of Challan') and Bajaj Finserv ('Provident Fund (PF) Due Dates in India & Late Payment ...'), damages under Section 14B were earlier levied on a slab basis on the arrears:
  • Delay up to 2 months: 5% per annum
  • Delay for 2–4 months: 10% per annum
  • Delay for 4–6 months: 15% per annum
  • Delay for more than 6 months: 25% per annum
  These slab rates (5% to 25% per annum) are still reflected in some older guidance articles and in the Acuity Law note ('EPFO: Revision to rate of damages payable by employers') describing the earlier regime.
- Revised damages (effective 14 June 2024 onward): As per the Ascent HR notification 'Reduction of penal damages under EPF, EPS, and EDLI ...' and corroborated by the Wisemonk penalties FAQ, the EPFO has, with effect from 14 June 2024, reduced penal damages to a uniform rate of 1% per month for EPF, EPS and EDLI, replacing the earlier 5%–25% per annum slabs. The Ascent HR source notes: 'Penal damages for EPF, EPS, and EDLI were reduced to 1% per month, effective June 14, 2024, from 5% to 25% previously. Interest remains at 12% ...'. Wisemonk summarises this as 'EPF Penalties: 1% monthly damages + 12% interest post-June 2024; imprisonment for severe defaults.'
  • The 1% per month is generally interpreted as 1% of the arrears for each month or part of a month of delay, i.e., approximately 12% per annum equivalent. It is levied in addition to 12% p.a. interest under Section 7Q.
  • No explicit statutory maximum amount per challan is specified in the search results; damages are proportional to the arrears and duration of default, subject to EPFO’s powers (e.g., possible waivers or reductions in certain limited circumstances as per the Act and EPFO policy).

3) Combined impact and example calculation (post–14 June 2024 regime):
- Assume an employer fails to pay ₹100,000 of EPF contributions for wage month April 2025 by the due date of 15 May 2025, and instead pays on 25 June 2025 (41 days late).
- Interest under Section 7Q at 12% p.a.:
  • Interest period: 16 May 2025 to 25 June 2025 (41 days).
  • Interest = ₹100,000 × 12% × (41/365) ≈ ₹100,000 × 0.12 × 0.1123 ≈ ₹1,347 (approx. ₹1,350).
- Damages under Section 14B at 1% per month:
  • Delay spans parts of two months (May and June), so effectively 2 months of delay.
  • Damages = ₹100,000 × 1% × 2 = ₹2,000.
- Total statutory financial impact (excluding any prosecution risk) ≈ ₹3,350 in this simplified illustration.

4) Prosecution and non-monetary consequences:
- The Wisemonk penalties FAQ notes that, beyond interest and damages, 'imprisonment for severe defaults' is possible. Under the EPF Act, wilful non-payment of contributions or repeated default can lead to criminal prosecution and imprisonment of responsible persons, in addition to recovery of dues, interest and damages.

5) Key points for SMEs:
- Interest under Section 7Q is automatic and non-discretionary; the EPFO system calculates it upon delayed payment, as confirmed in the ComplianceLetter_08102025 snippet.
- Damages under Section 14B have, from 14 June 2024 onward, been standardized at 1% per month (for EPF, EPS and EDLI), replacing the earlier higher slab rates of 5%–25% per annum that are still visible in older guidance pages.
- There is no separate per-day late fee; the effective daily cost is captured by the 12% p.a. interest plus the monthly 1% damages.

forms.name: Revamped Electronic Challan-cum-Return (New ECR) – Monthly EPF/EPS/EDLI Return (effective wage month September 2025 onwards)
forms.description:
The 'revamped' Electronic Challan-cum-Return (New ECR) is the updated monthly EPF/EPS/EDLI return and challan system introduced by EPFO for wage month September 2025 onwards. As per the official EPFO 'Revamped ECR' page ('EPFO will shortly be introducing the revamped Electronic Challan-cum-Return (ECR) for wage month Sept 2025 onwards with the following key features:') and the EPFO circular ECRRevamp_26092025.pdf ('The revamped ECR module is designed to streamline the return filing process for employers and establishments through the EPFO's employer ...'), the new module is intended to simplify and enhance the user experience of return filing via the EPFO employer portal. Key points from the search results:
- The revamped ECR is accessed through the EPFO employer portal, replacing the legacy ECR for wage month September 2025 and later.
- The system is designed to streamline return filing, with improved workflows and validations, though the detailed feature list is not fully visible in the snippets.
- Multiple sources (PIB Press Release on 13 October 2025, Legality Simplified article, Saral.pro blog, CNBC-TV18 article, CAalley news, Times of India article, and EPFO’s official Facebook post) confirm that the introduction of the revamped ECR for wage month September 2025 prompted EPFO to extend the filing deadline for that month to allow a smoother transition.

deadline.formula: For wage month September 2025 onwards, under the revamped ECR system, the standard statutory rule remains that the ECR must be filed and contributions remitted on or before the 15th day of the month following the wage month (the same rule that applies to the legacy ECR). Thus, for wage month October 2025, the ECR filing and payment deadline would ordinarily be 15 November 2025.
deadline.calculation:
Step 1: Determine the wage month for which the new ECR is being filed (e.g., September 2025).
Step 2: Identify the following calendar month (for September 2025, this is October 2025). This is the due month.
Step 3: The standard due date is the 15th of that due month (for September 2025 wages, this would ordinarily have been 15 October 2025).
Step 4: For wage month September 2025 only, EPFO provided an extension (see 'extensions' below), so the operational due date for the new ECR was moved to 22 October 2025. For subsequent months (e.g., October 2025 onwards), unless specifically extended, the due date reverts to the standard 15th of the next month.
Example (normal month, no extension): For wage month November 2025, the due month is December 2025 and the ECR plus payment should be completed by 15 December 2025.
deadline.gracePeriod: No standing grace period applies beyond the statutory 15th-of-next-month rule. Any deviations (such as the temporary September 2025 extension) are case-specific and notified via official circulars and press releases.
deadline.extensions:
Transition extension for wage month September 2025: Multiple 2025 sources confirm a one-time extension of the new ECR filing deadline while employers transitioned to the revamped system:
- PIB press release (13 October 2025, PRID=2178587, titled 'EPFO Extends date of filing of new ECR up to 22nd October ...') states that the date of filing of the new ECR for wage month September 2025 was extended up to 22 October 2025. The press release notes that the 'revamped system aims to simplify and enhance user experience of the return filing process for employers via the EPFO's employer portal.'
- The EPFO’s official Facebook post (Social EPFO) reiterates: 'The last date to file the new ECR for September 2025 has been extended till 22nd October 2025. The revamped system ensures easier ...'.
- Secondary sources (CAalley, Times of India, Saral.pro, Legality Simplified, CNBC-TV18) consistently report that employers were given 'one-week extension' or that 'deadline extended to October 22' for September 2025 wage month ECR.
Thus, for wage month September 2025 only, the due date for filing the revamped ECR and associated payment was 22 October 2025 instead of the usual 15 October 2025. For calculation of interest and damages for that specific month, the effective statutory due date is treated as 22 October 2025; interest under Section 7Q and damages under Section 14B would apply from 23 October 2025 if payment was made thereafter.

forms.penalty:
The penalty structure for the revamped (new) ECR is the same as for the legacy ECR because it is governed by the same statutory provisions of the EPF Act. Failure to file the new ECR and remit contributions by the applicable due date (normally the 15th of the following month, and for wage month September 2025, the extended due date of 22 October 2025) attracts:

1) Interest under Section 7Q at 12% per annum (simple interest) on the unpaid amount from the day after the applicable due date until the actual date of payment. As confirmed in the ComplianceLetter_08102025, this interest 'becomes automatically applicable (for delay in payment) and is computed by the system.'

2) Damages under Section 14B at 1% per month of delay (from 14 June 2024 onwards) for EPF, EPS and EDLI contributions, replacing the earlier slab-based damages of 5%–25% per annum reported in older guidance. The Ascent HR notification and Wisemonk penalties FAQ confirm that the current rate is 1% per month plus 12% interest post-June 2024.

3) For the special case of wage month September 2025, because EPFO expressly extended the filing deadline to 22 October 2025 via the PIB press release PRID=2178587 and other official communications, interest and damages would only start accruing for payments made after 22 October 2025 (i.e., from 23 October 2025) instead of from 16 October 2025. Employers who missed even the extended date would still be liable for 12% p.a. interest under Section 7Q and 1% per month damages under Section 14B, calculated from 23 October 2025.

4) In addition to interest and damages, significant or wilful defaults can trigger prosecution with potential imprisonment, as highlighted in the Wisemonk EPF/ESI penalties FAQ ('imprisonment for severe defaults').

contribution.employer:
Standard rate: For most covered establishments with 20 or more employees, the employer must contribute 12% of each covered employee's 'PF wages' (generally basic wages plus dearness allowance and retaining allowance, if any, and the cash value of food concessions, in line with the EPF Act definition). This is supported by multiple 2025 guidance sources, including Paytm's 'EPF Contribution Guide', Axis Bank's EPF article, Bajaj Finserv's 'How to Calculate Your Employer's EPF Contribution', and the Wisemonk FAQ on EPF rules in India 2025, all of which describe an employer contribution of 12% of the salary (typically basic + DA). The EPFO 'Present Rates of Contribution' PDF confirms the standard contribution rate of 12% and also notes a concessional 10% rate for certain establishments.

Break-up of the employer's 12% contribution (standard scenario):
- 8.33% of PF wages is allocated to the Employees' Pension Scheme (EPS), subject to the EPS wage ceiling (currently ₹15,000 per month), as reflected in BharatPayroll's 'EPFO Contribution Rate 2025' ('8.33% goes to the Employees Pension Scheme (EPS). It pays pension benefits.') and in multiple guidance sources (Axis Bank, Bajaj Finserv, ClearTax's 'EPF Interest Rate' article which uses 8.33% of ₹15,000 in its 2025 calculation example).
- The balance (12% − 8.33% = 3.67% of PF wages, plus any part of the 8.33% calculated on wages above the EPS ceiling) is credited to the Employees' Provident Fund (EPF) account. BharatPayroll summarises this as '3.67% goes to the Employees Provident Fund (EPF). It grows the retirement savings.'

Concessional rate establishments (10% contribution):
- The EPFO 'Present Rates of Contribution' PDF (ContributionRate.pdf) snippet states: 'EMPLOYEE 12% /10% ## 10% rate is applicable for • Any establishment in which less than 20 employees are employed. EPF Administrative charges is rounded. The ...'. This indicates that certain establishments, such as those with fewer than 20 employees (and other categories notified under the Act), may contribute at a reduced statutory rate of 10% of PF wages instead of 12%, with a corresponding 10% employee contribution. The detailed list of eligible industries is in the official PDF; the search snippets specifically highlight the employee-count condition.

Additional employer outgo (administrative and insurance):
- Although not fully detailed in the snippets, the EPFO 'Present Rates of Contribution' PDFs historically include employer contributions towards the Employees' Deposit-Linked Insurance (EDLI) Scheme (typically 0.5% of wages subject to a wage ceiling) and EPF administrative charges (historically around 0.5% of PF wages, subject to minimum amounts per establishment). The snippet 'EPF Administrative charges is rounded. The ...' confirms the existence of such charges in the current schedule, though the exact percentages and minimums are not fully visible in the search results. SMEs should refer directly to the latest 'ContributionRate.pdf' on epfindia.gov.in to confirm the current EDLI rate and EPF administrative charges applicable in 2025.
contribution.employee:
The employee's mandatory EPF contribution is ordinarily 12% of monthly PF wages, mirroring the employer's standard rate, as explained in Paytm's 'EPF Contribution Guide' ('The employee contribution is fixed at 12% of the sum of basic salary and DA. The employer also contributes an equal amount of 12%.') and in Shriram Finance's FAQ ('The EPF contribution rate for employees is 12% of basic salary and dearness allowance, with exceptions for certain establishments at 10%.'). In establishments eligible for the concessional rate, the employee contributes 10% instead of 12%, aligned with the EPFO 'Present Rates of Contribution' PDF which references 'EMPLOYEE 12% /10%' and a 10% rate for establishments with fewer than 20 employees.

Voluntary Provident Fund (VPF):
- The EPFO ComplianceLetter_08102025 explicitly notes: 'An employee can contribute more than 12% as Voluntary Provident Fund. (VPF) in their Provident Fund (PF) account, but the employer has the ...' (the remainder of the sentence is truncated in the snippet, but standard rules are that the employer is not required to match contributions beyond the statutory rate). This confirms that employees may voluntarily contribute more than the mandatory 12%, typically up to 100% of basic wages and DA, and such voluntary contributions are credited to the EPF account and earn the same rate of interest as mandatory contributions. Employers are not obligated to contribute more than the statutory employer rate (12% or 10%, as applicable) even if an employee opts for higher voluntary contributions.

Special notes:
- Guidance from the Wisemonk 'EPF rules in India 2025' FAQ reiterates that 'EPF contributions are mandatory for employers with 20+ employees, with 12% each from employer and employee.' It further states that 'The 2025 updates eliminate the ₹15,000 salary cap ...', which is understood as referring to the earlier practice of capping EPF contributions on wages of ₹15,000 per month; this suggests contributions should now be computed on full basic plus DA where higher than ₹15,000. However, as the underlying EPFO circular text is not visible in the snippets, employers should verify the operative wage basis directly from the latest official EPFO communications.
contribution.calculation:
High-level calculation method for a typical month (post-14 June 2024 regime, standard 12% rate):

Step 1 – Determine PF wages: Identify each covered employee's monthly 'PF wages'. Guidance pages (Paytm, Shriram Finance, Axis Bank, Bajaj Finserv) uniformly suggest using the sum of basic salary and dearness allowance (DA) as the base for EPF calculations; in legal terms, PF wages are generally basic wages plus DA and retaining allowance (if any) and the cash value of food concessions.

Step 2 – Compute employee contribution:
- Standard establishments: Employee contribution = 12% of PF wages.
- Concessional rate establishments (eligible for 10%): Employee contribution = 10% of PF wages.
- If the employee has opted for Voluntary Provident Fund (VPF), add any voluntary amount above the mandatory 12% (or 10%) contribution, up to the limit permitted by EPFO (typically up to 100% of basic + DA). The entire voluntary amount is credited to the EPF account.

Step 3 – Compute employer contribution (EPF + EPS):
- Determine the applicable contribution rate (12% or 10%).
- Apply the rate to PF wages to get the total employer contribution.
- Split the employer contribution between EPS and EPF:
  • EPS portion = 8.33% of PF wages, but only up to the EPS wage ceiling of ₹15,000 per month (maximum EPS contribution is therefore 8.33% × ₹15,000 = ₹1,250 per month per employee). This EPS split and ceiling are expressly illustrated in the ClearTax 'EPF Interest Rate' 2025 example ('Employer contribution to EPS (8.33% of Rs. 15,000): ...') and in BharatPayroll's 'EPFO Contribution Rate 2025' ('8.33% goes to the Employees Pension Scheme (EPS).').
  • EPF employer portion = Total employer contribution − EPS portion. In practice, for an employee earning above ₹15,000 per month, the EPS portion is capped at ₹1,250, and any remaining employer contribution (beyond ₹1,250) goes entirely to the EPF account.

Step 4 – Add EDLI and administrative charges (employer only):
- As per EPFO's 'Present Rates of Contribution' schedule (ContributionRate.pdf), the employer must also pay EDLI contribution and EPF administrative charges. While the snippets do not show the exact 2025 percentages, historically these have been around 0.5% of wages for EDLI (subject to the wage ceiling) and 0.5% of PF wages as EPF administrative charges, as indicated by the phrase 'EPF Administrative charges is rounded. The ...' in the EPFO PDF snippet. These charges are computed on eligible wages and added to the employer’s outgo but are not deducted from employees.

Simple numeric illustration (based on typical 2025 guidance) – Employee with PF wages of ₹25,000 per month in a standard 12% establishment:
- Employee contribution: 12% of ₹25,000 = ₹3,000 (all to EPF; may be higher if VPF elected).
- Employer total contribution: 12% of ₹25,000 = ₹3,000.
  • EPS portion: 8.33% of ₹15,000 (capped) = ₹1,250 to EPS.
  • EPF employer portion: ₹3,000 − ₹1,250 = ₹1,750 to EPF.
- Total credited to EPF account for the month: Employee ₹3,000 + Employer EPF ₹1,750 = ₹4,750.
- Total credited to EPS: ₹1,250.
- Employer additionally pays EDLI and EPF administrative charges as per EPFO's current rate schedule (exact percentages to be verified in ContributionRate.pdf).

This structure is consistent with the guidance examples on ClearTax (EPF interest calculation 2025), Axis Bank, Bajaj Finserv, BharatPayroll 2025 and other sources in the search results.
contribution.wageCeiling:
EPS wage ceiling (current): The statutory wage ceiling for the Employees' Pension Scheme (EPS) is ₹15,000 per month. Accordingly, the maximum EPS contribution is 8.33% × ₹15,000 = ₹1,250 per month per employee. ClearTax's 2025 interest example explicitly uses 'Employer contribution to EPS (8.33% of Rs. 15,000)' to illustrate this cap, and BharatPayroll and Axis Bank articles reiterate the same concept.

Historical EPF contribution wage ceilings (from EPFO 'Present Rates of Contribution_till04012016.pdf' and later practice):
- The older EPFO contribution rate PDF ('ContributionRate_till04012016.pdf') snippet states: 'The contributions are payable on maximum wage ceiling of Rs 6500/- by employee ...', indicating that prior to subsequent amendments, contributions were capped on wages of ₹6,500 per month. This is a historical threshold and no longer applies at current rates.
- Subsequent updates (not fully reproduced in the snippets but well recognised in practice) increased the wage ceiling from ₹6,500 to ₹15,000 per month.

2025 guidance on salary cap removal for EPF contributions: The Wisemonk FAQ 'What are EPF rules in India 2025 & how the system operates' states: 'EPF contributions are mandatory for employers with 20+ employees, with 12% each from employer and employee.' It further notes: 'The 2025 updates eliminate the ₹15,000 salary cap ...'. While the snippet does not show the full sentence, the context indicates that the prior practice of limiting EPF contributions (especially for higher-salaried employees) to a wage base of ₹15,000 per month has been removed, suggesting that, for EPF (as distinct from EPS), contributions should be computed on full basic pay plus DA even where wages exceed ₹15,000. The EPS wage ceiling of ₹15,000 remains in place for the 8.33% pension contribution component. Because the underlying EPFO notification text is not included in the snippets, SMEs should confirm the operative wage ceiling policy directly from the latest EPFO circulars and internal counsel; however, the guidance in the search results clearly signals a 2025 shift away from the ₹15,000 cap for EPF contribution calculations.
