Section 234E: Fee & Penalty for Late Filing of TDS/TCS Returns (ClearTax)
TDS Defaults: Notices, Penalties & Resolution Process

additionalInfo.registration: Any person (including SMEs, startups, MSMEs) required to deduct or collect TDS/TCS must obtain a Tax Deduction and Collection Account Number (TAN) under section 203A before initiating deductions. TAN is quoted on Challan ITNS 281 and all TDS/TCS statements (Forms 24Q, 26Q, 27Q, 27EQ). Exceptions: certain 'specified persons' under section 194S (VDA) enjoy a threshold of Rs 50,000 and are not required to obtain TAN, as noted in the RSM India snippet. Registration on the Income Tax e‑Filing portal and TRACES portal is required for e‑filing statements, downloading Form 16/16A, and viewing defaults. PAN is mandatory for the deductor; PAN of deductees is required to avoid higher TDS and matching issues.
additionalInfo.renewal: TAN and PAN are permanent identifiers and do not require periodic renewal. However, TDS registration on the e‑Filing and TRACES portals may require re‑authentication (for example, re‑registration of digital signatures, password resets). SMEs must renew digital signature certificates (DSCs) periodically as per DSC validity but there is no separate TDS 'license' renewal.
additionalInfo.filingMethod: TDS/TCS returns (Forms 24Q, 26Q, 27Q, 27EQ) must be filed electronically. Deductors typically: (1) use a Return Preparation Utility (RPU) and File Validation Utility (FVU) (from NSDL/Protean or other vendors) to prepare a text file in the prescribed schema; (2) log in to the Income Tax e‑Filing portal (https://www.incometax.gov.in/) using TAN credentials; (3) upload the validated FVU file under TDS/TCS section; and (4) verify using Digital Signature Certificate (DSC), Electronic Verification Code (EVC) or as prescribed. Earlier, filing could also be done at TIN‑FCs but the standard mode is now online. Payment of TDS/TCS via Challan ITNS 281 is made either: (a) through authorised bank branches (physical challan with cheque/cash) or (b) via net banking or NEFT/RTGS through the OLTAS/e‑payment facility, selecting Challan 281 and providing TAN, AY, and section codes. TRACES portal is used post‑filing to download Consolidated Files, Justification Reports, and Form 16/16A and to respond to TDS defaults.
additionalInfo.prerequisites: Key prerequisites for TDS compliance by SMEs/MSMEs include: (1) Valid TAN and PAN of the deductor; (2) PAN (or Aadhaar, where permitted) of all deductees to avoid higher TDS rates and credit mismatches; (3) Accounting systems capable of tracking section‑wise taxable payments, thresholds, and due dates; (4) Knowledge of applicable TDS sections and rates using current FY rate charts (such as those published by ClearTax, TDSMAN, IndiaFilings, Kotak Life, PNB MetLife, RSM etc.); (5) Access to e‑Filing and TRACES portals; (6) Digital Signature Certificate where required; (7) Mechanism to compute interest under section 201(1A) and late fees under section 234E when there is any delay; and (8) Robust vendor and employee onboarding processes to capture PAN, residency status, and treaty details (for non‑residents).
additionalInfo.recentUpdates: Key updates and 2025‑specific points drawn from the search results are: (1) Relaxation of multiple TDS thresholds from FY 2025-26 – ClearTax’s FY 2025-26 TDS rate chart notes that 'TDS threshold limits has been relaxed for many important sections with effect from this year' and that 'TDS rates have remained mostly unchanged', implying that many SMEs may fall below TDS applicability for certain small-value payments; users should consult the full section‑wise table for exact revised limits. (2) Increased threshold for senior citizens' bank interest – Kotak Life’s FY 2025-26 rate chart highlights that 'the main changes from April 2025 involve increased threshold limits'. Specifically, it mentions that 'the TDS limit for interest paid by banks to senior citizens is ...', indicating that the Rs 50,000 exemption limit under section 194A for senior citizens has been increased from 1 April 2025, though the snippet does not show the exact new amount. (3) Higher threshold for payments to co‑operative societies – IndiaFilings’ FY 2025-26 rate chart snippet states that 'the TDS limit, in case if the recipient is co-operative society, will be INR 3 Crores instead of INR 1 Crore', signifying a tripling of the exemption limit for a specific TDS provision involving co‑operative society recipients (section reference not shown in snippet). (4) Introduction of section 194T – PNB MetLife’s FY 2024-25 TDS chart notes that 'Section 194T introduces 10% TDS on firm-to-partner payments exceeding Rs.20,000', creating a new TDS obligation on certain firm‑to‑partner payments beyond Rs 20,000 in a financial year. (5) Continued operation of section 206AB (higher TDS for specified non-filers) – PNB MetLife’s chart notes that 'Higher TDS for non-filers under 206AB ensures tax compliance', reminding SMEs that certain payees who have not filed returns in previous years and meet the 'specified person' definition can attract higher TDS rates (typically higher of twice the rate specified, twice the rate in force, or 5%), although exact formula details are not in the snippets. (6) Rate changes mid‑year for FY 2024-25 – Setindiabiz’s 'Updated TDS Rates & Thresholds for FY 2024-25' specifies that 'Rates change mid-year on Oct 1, 2024', meaning that for some sections, there are distinct rates for 1 April–30 September 2024 and 1 October 2024–31 March 2025; SMEs must check which half‑year rate applies to a given payment date. (7) Removal of section 271H penalty for mere late filing from AY 2025-26 – The Income Tax Department’s late-filing/penalty tutorial (30 September 2025) states that 'with effect from Assessment Year 2025-26, no penalty under section 271H will be levied in case of delay in filing the TDS/TCS ...'. AngelOne’s article on the Income Tax (No. 2) Bill, 2025 echoes that 'under the new provisions, there will be no financial penalty if a taxpayer files their TDS returns late', meaning that from AY 2025-26 onward, routine late filing is subject to section 234E fees but not 271H penalty, although incorrect statements may still face penal consequences. (8) Confirmation of section 234E regime – Multiple 2025 guidance articles (ClearTax’s section 234E piece, Bajaj Finserv’s 234E article, Kotak Life’s penalty article, RegisterKaro’s note, and Figment Global’s example) reaffirm that late filing of TDS/TCS statements triggers a fee of Rs 200 per day, capped at the TDS/TCS amount, and that this fee is separate from interest under section 201(1A). (9) Emphasis on monthly 7th‑day deposit and extended March deadline – ClearTax, SAG Infotech, Jainam and Bajaj Finserv confirm that the 'due date for depositing TDS amount is usually the 7th of the next month', with an extended deadline for March (statutorily 30 April) highlighted as a specific exception in Bajaj Finserv’s FY 2025-26 article. (10) Advanced due dates for FY 2025-26 non‑salary TDS returns – Kotak Life’s 'TDS Return Due Dates of FY 2025-26' snippet explicitly changes the Q1 and Q2 due dates for Forms 26Q and 27Q to 15 July and 15 October respectively, while Form 24Q remains 31 July; SMEs must update compliance calendars accordingly. (11) MSME/Startup focus – Ricago’s 2025 blog on TDS/TCS compliances for Startups and MSMEs underscores that each TDS/TCS section has specific rates, thresholds and compliance requirements, and that 2025 changes (such as higher thresholds and removal of some penalties) are particularly relevant to smaller entities looking to simplify compliance. SMEs should systematically map their payment types to sections, apply the correct FY 2024-25 or 2025-26 rate chart, and monitor ongoing Finance Act changes.

msme-annual-return.name: MSME Delayed Payment Half-Yearly Return (Form MSME-1) and Udyam Registration Annual Update

applicability.condition: This compliance covers two connected obligations affecting Indian MSMEs and companies dealing with them: (1) Half-yearly reporting in Form MSME-1: Every company incorporated under the Companies Act, 2013 (including private, public, listed, unlisted and foreign companies having a place of business in India) that procures goods or services from suppliers classified as Micro or Small Enterprises under the Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises Development Act, 2006 (MSMED Act) and has payments outstanding to such suppliers for more than 45 days from the date of acceptance or deemed acceptance of the goods or services must file a half-yearly return in Form MSME-1 with the Registrar of Companies (ROC) under Section 405 of the Companies Act, 2013 and the Specified Companies (Furnishing of information about payment to micro and small enterprise suppliers) Order, 2019. This return reports delayed payments to MSME suppliers. Professional sources such as ClearTax, TaxGuru, LegalWiz, Bajaj Finserv, CAMF Khan, SAG Infotech, Tally Solutions and StartupFlora all describe Form MSME-1 as a mandatory half-yearly ROC filing for such specified companies when payments to MSME suppliers remain unpaid beyond 45 days. (2) Udyam Registration Annual Update: Every enterprise that has obtained MSME (Udyam) registration on the official Udyam Registration portal of the Ministry of Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (udyamregistration.gov.in) is required to keep its registration data updated online on that portal, including turnover and investment data sourced from its Income Tax Return (ITR) and GST returns. Professional commentary (e.g., StartupFlora and IndiaFilings) refers to this as an 'MSME Udyam Annual Update' and explains that the Ministry uses ITR and GSTN data from relevant financial years (for example, IndiaFilings notes that for 2022–2023 classification, data from 2020–2021 were used), so MSMEs should update their Udyam details at least annually once their tax data are finalised.
exemptions: Form MSME-1 applies only to 'companies' as defined under the Companies Act, 2013. Entities that are not companies – such as sole proprietorships, traditional partnerships, LLPs, societies and trusts – are not required to file MSME-1 even if they have delayed payments to MSMEs; their obligations towards MSMEs are governed directly by the MSMED Act but not by this ROC return.

The MSME-1 obligation applies only in respect of dues owed to suppliers that qualify as Micro or Small Enterprises under the MSMED Act and that are registered as MSMEs (now via Udyam). Outstanding payments to 'Medium' enterprises are not reportable in MSME-1.

Professional guidance (e.g., ClearTax, LegalWiz, TaxGuru, CAMF Khan, SAG Infotech) focuses MSME-1 on situations where payments to MSME suppliers are outstanding for more than 45 days. Companies that have no such suppliers, or that pay all MSME suppliers within 45 days so that no eligible invoices are outstanding during a half-year, are generally treated as outside the scope of MSME-1 for that period; many advisers therefore consider that a 'nil' MSME-1 is not required, though some companies still choose to file a nil return as a conservative compliance practice.

Udyam registration (MSME registration) itself is not legally mandatory for running a business (private platforms such as msme-form.org explicitly note that MSME registration is not compulsory), but registration is a precondition for being formally recognised as an MSME, for availing MSME-linked government benefits and schemes, and for being treated as an MSME supplier for the purposes of delayed payment protection and MSME-1 reporting by buyer companies.

forms.name: Form MSME-1 (MSME Form 1) – Half-Yearly Return on Delayed Payments to Micro and Small Enterprise Suppliers
forms.description: Form MSME-1 (commonly referred to as MSME Form 1) is a half-yearly e-form prescribed by the Ministry of Corporate Affairs (MCA) to be filed with the Registrar of Companies (ROC) under Section 405 of the Companies Act, 2013 read with the Specified Companies (Furnishing of information about payment to micro and small enterprise suppliers) Order, 2019. It must be filed by 'specified companies' that obtain goods or services from suppliers classified as Micro or Small Enterprises (MSEs) under the MSMED Act, 2006 and that have payments to such suppliers remaining unpaid for more than 45 days from the date of acceptance or deemed acceptance. The form reports details of outstanding amounts and delays so that the government can monitor whether companies are honouring the MSMED Act’s mandate for timely payment to small suppliers. The latest V3 version of the form on the MCA V3 portal, discussed in 2025 articles such as TaxGuru’s 'New MSME-1 (V3) Era: Don’t Miss These Hidden Compliance Triggers' and Tally Solutions’ 'MSME Form 1 Reporting Changes – Key Updates for 2025', has enhanced data fields. It requires: (a) company information (CIN/FCRN, name, registered office address, email ID, PAN), (b) the return type and reporting half-year (April–September or October–March), and (c) supplier-wise information for each Micro or Small Enterprise to whom payments have been delayed beyond 45 days, including supplier name, Udyam Registration Number or other MSME registration details, amount due, date from which the amount has been outstanding, and reasons for the delay, as well as disclosure related to interest under the MSMED Act. Its policy objective, highlighted across multiple guides (ClearTax, LegalWiz, Bajaj Finserv, CAMF Khan, SAG Infotech and TaxGuru), is to enforce payment discipline towards MSMEs and to provide transparency of chronic payment delays.

deadline.formula: MSME-1 is filed twice each financial year with two fixed statutory due dates: (1) For the half-year from 1 April to 30 September, Form MSME-1 must be filed on or before 31 October of the same calendar year. (2) For the half-year from 1 October to 31 March, Form MSME-1 must be filed on or before 30 April of the immediately following calendar year. These dates are consistently quoted in professional guidance: StartupFlora’s 'MSME Return Due Date – Complete Guide for 2025' table lists 'MSME Form 1 (Half-yearly Return), 30 April (for Oct–Mar) & 31 October (for Apr–Sep)', and similar due date descriptions appear in articles by Bajaj Finserv, LegalWiz, SAG Infotech, ClearTax and TaxGuru.
deadline.calculation: Step 1: Identify all suppliers that qualify as Micro or Small Enterprises under the MSMED Act and that have valid MSME/Udyam registration (many guides advise obtaining a copy of the Udyam certificate or URN). Step 2: For each such MSME supplier, list all invoices or dues where payment is still outstanding. Step 3: For each invoice, determine the 'date of acceptance' or 'deemed acceptance' of the goods or services as per the MSMED Act. Step 4: Calculate the 45th day from this acceptance date. If the invoice remains unpaid after this 45-day point, it becomes reportable in MSME-1. Step 5: Allocate each delayed invoice to the appropriate half-year based on when the delay beyond 45 days occurs and whether it remains outstanding at the end of that half-year. Example A (April–September period): An invoice from a micro enterprise supplier is dated and accepted on 1 May 2025. The 45-day limit expires on 15 June 2025. If the payment is still outstanding on and after 16 June 2025 and remains unpaid at 30 September 2025, the invoice is reportable in MSME-1 for the half-year 1 April 2025 to 30 September 2025, which must be filed by 31 October 2025. Example B (October–March period): An invoice is accepted on 10 January 2026. The 45-day limit expires on 24 February 2026. If it is unpaid beyond 24 February 2026 and remains unpaid at 31 March 2026, it must be reported in the MSME-1 for the half-year 1 October 2025 to 31 March 2026, due by 30 April 2026.
deadline.gracePeriod: Neither Section 405 of the Companies Act nor the Specified Companies Order, 2019 provides a statutory grace period beyond the due dates of 31 October and 30 April. A delay of even one day technically constitutes a filing default exposed to penalty. Any condonation of delay would have to be obtained through the adjudication and condonation mechanisms under the Companies Act on a case-by-case basis.
deadline.extensions: The 2024–25 and 2025 professional commentary referenced in the search results (including TaxGuru’s 31 October 2025 MSME-1 article, SAG Infotech’s November 2025 'Easy Guide to MSME Form 1', ClearTax’s April 2025 MSME-1 guide, CAMF Khan’s May 2025 article, StartupFlora’s 2025 due date guide, and Tally Solutions’ June 2025 piece on reporting changes) do not mention any general MCA circular granting blanket extensions of MSME-1 due dates for the reporting periods covering FY 2024–25 or 2025–26. Any extensions, if granted in future, would need to be checked directly on mca.gov.in or through MCA circulars for the relevant year.

forms.penalty: There is no government filing fee for submitting Form MSME-1; CAMF Khan’s 2025 article explicitly states 'Filing Fees: There is no fee for filing Form MSME-1.' However, non-compliance with MSME-1 requirements attracts penalties under Section 405(4) of the Companies Act, 2013, as synthesised from multiple 2024–25 professional sources (ClearTax, SAG Infotech, RegistrationWala, CompanySuggestion, TaxGuru, CAMF Khan, StartupFlora and TaxScan): (1) Trigger for penalty: failure to file MSME-1 within the prescribed time, furnishing incomplete or incorrect information, or non-compliance with an order requiring information/statistics under Section 405. (2) Base (one-time) penalty: ClearTax’s April 2025 MSME-1 guide and RegistrationWala’s June 2025 MSME-1 article state that if a company fails to file MSME-1, the company and every officer in default will be liable to a penalty of about ₹20,000 each. CAMF Khan’s May 2025 write-up refers to this as a fine 'up to ₹25,000' on the company, reflecting the statutory wording that the penalty may extend to ₹25,000. StartupFlora’s 2025 due date article summarises that penalties for MSME return non-compliance can range from ₹25,000 to ₹1,00,000, depending on circumstances, which is within the broader statutory range used in practice. (3) Per-day penalty for continuing default: SAG Infotech’s 2025 guide (quoting Section 405(4)) and RegistrationWala’s June 2025 article state that in case of continuing failure there is a further fine of ₹1,000 for every day during which the default continues. CompanySuggestion’s July 2024 article on adjudicating penalty for delayed MSME filing also notes an 'additional penalty of ₹1,000 for every day during which the failure continues.' (4) Maximum penalty cap: TaxScan’s April 2025 news item reports that companies may face penalty 'up to ₹3 lakh' for not filing MSME-1, and CompanySuggestion mentions that the per-day penalty is 'subject to a maximum', which aligns with the adjudication framework where total penalty on each defaulter is typically capped at ₹3,00,000. Accordingly, a widely used working model in 2025 professional practice is: Company – base penalty of about ₹20,000 plus ₹1,000 per day of continuing default, capped at a total of ₹3,00,000; Officers in default – similar daily penalty structure, again capped at ₹3,00,000 per officer. (5) Filing fee vs. penalty: there is no ROC filing fee for timely MSME-1; the amounts described above are penalties imposed through adjudication if the company defaults. (6) Interest: no interest rate is prescribed on the MSME-1 filing itself. Separately, under the MSMED Act, if a buyer delays payment to a registered micro or small enterprise beyond the agreed date or 45 days, the buyer is liable to pay compound interest with monthly rests at three times the Reserve Bank of India’s bank rate to the supplier. This interest obligation is independent of MSME-1 but is closely related, as MSME-1 disclosure highlights the delayed payments on which such interest may accrue. (7) Practical application: the exact penalty imposed in any case depends on ROC adjudication, taking into account length of delay, number of invoices/suppliers affected, prior defaults, and whether there was wilful concealment or only technical breach.

forms.name: Udyam Annual Update – Online Update of MSME (Udyam) Registration Details
forms.description: The Udyam Annual Update is not a numbered statutory form but an online updating process for enterprises that have already obtained MSME registration (Udyam Registration Number) through the official Udyam Registration portal of the Ministry of Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (udyamregistration.gov.in). The process is commonly referred to in professional guides such as StartupFlora’s 'MSME Return Due Date – Complete Guide for 2025' as the 'MSME Udyam Annual Update'. It involves logging into the Udyam portal and updating enterprise data, including address, contact details, bank details, number of employees, and, critically, financial data on investment in plant and machinery or equipment and turnover. IndiaFilings’ article 'MSME Clarification on Selection of Financial Year for Udyam Registration' explains that for determining MSME classification the Ministry fetches data from the Income Tax and GSTN systems for a relevant financial year (for example, for classification applicable in 2022–2023, data from 2020–2021 were used), underscoring that the Udyam portal relies on tax-return data and expects enterprises to keep their Udyam profiles aligned with filed ITRs and GST returns. The core purpose of the Udyam Annual Update is therefore to keep MSME classification (Micro/Small/Medium) and other enterprise information current so that benefits, protections (including MSMED Act delayed payment protections) and various verification processes (such as buyers checking MSME status before reporting in MSME-1) are based on accurate data.

deadline.formula: The Udyam framework requires enterprises that have obtained an Udyam Registration Number to update their information on the Udyam portal periodically based on their latest Income Tax Returns and GST returns. Professional sources in the search results describe this as an 'annual update', but they do not specify an exact statutory calendar due date such as '31 March' or '31 December'. Rather, the expectation is that each enterprise should log into the Udyam portal at least once every financial year, after its ITR and GST data for the previous year are available, and update its investment and turnover figures and any other details requested by the portal. The Ministry then uses those updated values, together with data obtained from the Income Tax and GSTN back-end systems (as highlighted by IndiaFilings’ clarification article), to confirm or revise the enterprise’s classification as Micro, Small or Medium. The specific timing windows, if any, are operationally controlled by the portal and may be communicated through portal messages rather than fixed in the text of the notification.
deadline.calculation: Step 1: After the close of a financial year, finalise and file the enterprise’s Income Tax Return and applicable GST returns. Step 2: Extract key data from those returns: turnover for the year and investment in plant and machinery or equipment, as defined by the MSME classification rules. Step 3: Log into the official Udyam Registration portal (udyamregistration.gov.in) using the enterprise’s Udyam Registration Number and the registered mobile number or Aadhaar-based OTP authentication. Step 4: Enter or confirm updated details in the portal’s update interface – including turnover, investment, employment, contact information and any other fields requested – ensuring that the figures match those in the filed ITR and GST returns. Step 5: Submit the update and download or save any revised Udyam certificate or acknowledgment generated by the portal. Because the Ministry may rely on prior-year tax data (for example, IndiaFilings notes that FY 2020–21 data were used for 2022–23 classification), enterprises should follow any specific instructions or timelines indicated on the Udyam portal for when to perform the update.
deadline.gracePeriod: Neither the 2024–25 MSME Annual Report nor the professional commentary in the search results specify a grace period tied to a fixed statutory date for Udyam updates. The legal framework instead expects enterprises to keep information up to date on an ongoing basis, with the practice framed as an at-least-annual update aligned with tax filings.
deadline.extensions: The search results do not show any 2025-wide extension or amnesty for updating Udyam details; any relaxation or special window for corrections would normally be communicated directly via announcements on udyamregistration.gov.in or through Ministry of MSME notifications, which should be checked at the time of compliance.

forms.penalty: There is no government filing fee for updating an existing Udyam Registration, and none of the cited 2024–25 professional sources mention a fixed monetary penalty, per-day late fee, or interest charge specifically for failing to carry out the 'Udyam Annual Update'. Instead, the consequences of not updating are regulatory and practical rather than fee-based: (1) Suspension or deactivation of MSME status: the Udyam notification empowers the Ministry to suspend or deactivate an enterprise’s MSME registration if it fails to update its information within the period specified on the portal. During suspension, the enterprise may not be treated as an active MSME for purposes of schemes or verification. (2) Loss or blocking of benefits: if data are outdated, the enterprise may face difficulty in availing MSME-specific benefits, subsidies, or priority in government tenders and schemes until it regularises its Udyam record. (3) Misclassification risk: if turnover or investment has increased or decreased significantly but has not been updated, the portal may show an incorrect classification (e.g., still Micro when it should be Small), which can create issues when buyers, banks or government departments verify MSME status, and may also complicate enforcement of MSMED Act payment protections. (4) No statutory interest rate or per-day monetary penalty is specified in the search results for late updating itself. The key compliance risk is therefore loss or suspension of MSME recognition rather than an explicit rupee-denominated late fee.

forms.name: Form AOC-4 – Filing of Financial Statements with Registrar of Companies
forms.description: Form AOC-4 is the e-form prescribed by the Ministry of Corporate Affairs for filing a company’s financial statements with the Registrar of Companies under Section 137 of the Companies Act, 2013. It covers documents such as the balance sheet, statement of profit and loss, cash flow statement (where applicable), notes, and related attachments. While AOC-4 is a general corporate compliance form and not specific to MSMEs, it is highly relevant to MSMEs that are incorporated as companies (private limited, public limited, etc.), and therefore appears in the '2025 Compliance Checklist for Indian Startups & MSMEs' by TMWala alongside MSME-1 and other filings. The checklist notes that AOC-4 forms part of the core annual statutory compliances that MSME companies must observe in addition to MSME-specific reporting like MSME-1.

deadline.formula: Under Section 137 of the Companies Act, 2013, Form AOC-4 must be filed with the Registrar of Companies within 30 days from the date on which the company’s Annual General Meeting (AGM) is held to adopt the financial statements. TMWala’s '2025 Compliance Checklist for Indian Startups & MSMEs' summarises this by stating that AOC-4 must be filed within 30 days of the AGM. If, for any reason, an AGM is not actually held, the due date for AOC-4 is computed from the last date on which the AGM should have been held under the Act.
deadline.calculation: Step 1: Determine the company’s financial year-end (for most companies this is 31 March). Step 2: Identify the statutory deadline for holding the AGM for that financial year (normally within six months of the financial year-end, i.e., by 30 September, subject to any year-specific extensions granted by the ROC). Step 3: Note the actual date on which the AGM is held and the financial statements are adopted. If the AGM is not held, use the last date by which the AGM should have been held. Step 4: Starting from the AGM date, count 30 calendar days; the last of these days is the due date for filing AOC-4. Example: If the AGM for FY 2024–25 is held on 30 September 2025, AOC-4 must be filed on or before 30 October 2025.
deadline.gracePeriod: The Companies Act does not provide an automatic grace period beyond the 30-day limit. Delays beyond this limit attract additional filing fees and may lead to adjudication of penalties. In exceptional situations (for example, widespread disruptions), the MCA can extend due dates by issuing general circulars, but the 2025 materials in the search results do not report any such blanket extension for AOC-4 for FY 2024–25.
deadline.extensions: The TMWala 2025 compliance checklist and the IndiaFilings article on penalties for not filing annual returns do not refer to any specific 2025 extensions for AOC-4. Companies must track MCA general circulars and ROC notifications applicable to the particular financial year to know if any extension is granted.

forms.penalty: The IndiaFilings article 'Penalty for Not Filing Annual Return' explains that, with effect from 1 July 2018, the penalty/fee exposure for failing to file a company’s annual return (Form MGT-7) and financial statements (Form AOC-4) was increased so that delays attract a per-day additional fee. The article states that 'the penalty for not filing a companies annual return (Form MGT-7 and Form AOC-4) would be increased to Rs.200 per day from 1st July 2018.' In practical terms, this corresponds to additional filing fees of approximately ₹100 per day for each delayed form, i.e., ₹100 per day for AOC-4 and, if both AOC-4 and MGT-7 are delayed, a combined effect of ₹200 per day until filing. These per-day additional fees accumulate from the day after the statutory due date up to the actual date of filing. Beyond additional fees, the Companies Act also provides for separate penalties on the company and its officers in default for failure to file AOC-4 within time, which can include fixed penalties plus per-day components, but the detailed slab amounts are not set out in the search results. No interest rate is prescribed; the financial burden is a linear function of the number of days of delay multiplied by the per-day additional fee, plus any adjudicated penalties if imposed.

forms.name: Form MGT-7 / MGT-7A – Annual Return of Company
forms.description: Form MGT-7 is the e-form used by companies to file their annual return with the Registrar of Companies under Section 92 of the Companies Act, 2013. Form MGT-7A is a simplified version of this annual return for small companies and One Person Companies (OPCs). The annual return captures information such as shareholding pattern, debenture holdings, details of directors and key managerial personnel, meetings of members and board, and other statutory disclosures. While not MSME-specific, MGT-7/MGT-7A is part of the baseline corporate compliance framework for all companies, including those that are MSMEs. The TMWala '2025 Compliance Checklist for Indian Startups & MSMEs' notes that Forms AOC-4 and MGT-7 relate to financial statements and annual returns respectively and must be filed within 30 and 60 days of the AGM, underscoring their importance for MSME companies alongside sectoral compliances like MSME-1.

deadline.formula: Under Section 92 of the Companies Act, 2013, Form MGT-7 or MGT-7A must be filed within 60 days from the date of the company’s Annual General Meeting (AGM). TMWala’s 2025 compliance checklist for startups and MSMEs states that 'Filing of AOC-4 and MGT-7: These forms relate to financial statements and annual returns, respectively, and must be filed within 30 and 60 days of the AGM.' If an AGM is not actually held, the due date is computed from the date on which the AGM should statutorily have been held.
deadline.calculation: Step 1: Identify the company’s financial year-end (typically 31 March). Step 2: Determine the date on which the AGM was held for that financial year; if it was not held, determine the last statutory date by which it should have been held. Step 3: Starting from the AGM date (or deemed date), count 60 calendar days; the last of those days is the due date for filing MGT-7/MGT-7A. Example: If the AGM for FY 2024–25 is held on 30 September 2025, the due date for MGT-7 is 29 November 2025.
deadline.gracePeriod: The Companies Act does not provide a built-in grace period beyond the 60 days allowed for filing the annual return. Late filing leads to additional fees and may trigger adjudication of penalties. Extensions, when granted (for example in exceptional years), are notified separately by the MCA but no such general extension for FY 2024–25 is mentioned in the search results.
deadline.extensions: The 2025-focused sources in the search results, including TMWala’s compliance checklist and the IndiaFilings penalty article, do not indicate any specific 2025 extension of the statutory 60-day deadline for MGT-7/MGT-7A. Companies should monitor MCA circulars relevant to the financial year concerned for any relaxations.

forms.penalty: IndiaFilings’ article on the penalty for not filing annual returns explains that, effective 1 July 2018, the fee and penalty structure for failure to file both the annual return (MGT-7) and the financial statements (AOC-4) was revised so that a significant per-day additional fee is levied. The article states that 'the penalty for not filing a companies annual return (Form MGT-7 and Form AOC-4) would be increased to Rs.200 per day from 1st July 2018.' This is generally interpreted in practice as an additional fee of ₹100 per day for each delayed form, i.e., ₹100 per day for MGT-7 and, if both AOC-4 and MGT-7 are delayed, a combined additional fee impact of around ₹200 per day until both are filed. These fees accrue from the day after the statutory due date until the filing date. In addition, the Companies Act prescribes separate penalties for non-filing or delayed filing of MGT-7, imposed on the company and on officers in default through adjudication, but the detailed numerical slabs for those penalties are not described in the search results and so are not restated here. No specific interest rate applies; the cost of delay scales with the number of days of default and the per-day additional fees, plus any adjudicated penalties.

additionalInfo.registration: For MSME-1: There is no separate registration process for Form MSME-1. Any company that is already incorporated and has a Corporate Identity Number (CIN) or Foreign Company Registration Number (FCRN) on the MCA portal can file MSME-1 using its existing credentials. The company must maintain an up-to-date master data profile on the MCA portal (registered email, authorised signatories, and Digital Signature Certificates) since the MSME-1 e-form is filed electronically. For MSMEs (suppliers): To be treated as an MSME for payment protection and MSME-1 reporting, a supplier must be registered under the MSMED Act, which is now implemented through Udyam Registration on the official portal udyamregistration.gov.in. Multiple guidance sources (ClearTax’s MSME registration article, Filingg’s 2025 Udyam registration guide, and msme-form.org) describe the registration process: it is online, generally free on the government portal, and requires Aadhaar of the proprietor/partner/director, PAN, and key business details. Registration is not mandatory to run a business, but is essential for being recognised as an MSME and for buyers to be obligated to report delayed payments in MSME-1. For Udyam Annual Update: Only enterprises that have already obtained an Udyam Registration Number can perform the annual update. Login typically uses the Udyam Registration Number along with OTP sent to the registered mobile number and/or Aadhaar authentication.
additionalInfo.renewal: MSME-1 itself does not involve any renewal; it is a periodic half-yearly return. Companies simply continue to file it for each relevant half-year in which there are reportable delays to MSE suppliers. Udyam registration under the current framework is generally treated as valid for the lifetime of the enterprise, subject to the requirement that information (especially financial data) be periodically updated. There is no separate time-bound 'renewal' of Udyam registration in the sense of reapplying for a new registration number, but the annual update of information serves a similar function in keeping the registration active and accurate. Failure to update can lead to suspension or deactivation until the data are brought up to date.
additionalInfo.filingMethod: Form MSME-1 is filed electronically on the MCA V3 portal. The latest V3 version of MSME-1, discussed in TaxGuru’s 2025 'MSME-1 V3 Era' article and Tally Solutions’ 2025 update note, is an online e-form that captures company and supplier-wise data. The form is prepared and submitted online by an authorised signatory of the company using a valid Digital Signature Certificate (DSC), and may require certification by a practising professional (CA/CS/CMA) depending on MCA requirements at the time of filing. There is no government filing fee. Udyam Annual Update is completed entirely online on the official Udyam Registration portal (udyamregistration.gov.in). The enterprise logs in using its Udyam Registration Number and receives OTPs on the registered mobile number; details are updated on-screen and submitted digitally. No physical filings are involved. Forms AOC-4 and MGT-7/MGT-7A are also filed online on the MCA portal using DSCs, with payment of normal filing fees plus any applicable additional fees for late filing. Professional guidance (e.g., TMWala and IndiaFilings) emphasises that for MSMEs operating as companies, these ROC e-filings are as important as sector-specific returns like MSME-1.
additionalInfo.prerequisites: For MSME-1: (1) Identification of MSME suppliers – the company must identify which of its suppliers qualify as Micro or Small Enterprises under the MSMED Act. Guidance such as StartupFlora’s 2025 MSME return article recommends obtaining a copy of each supplier’s Udyam Registration Certificate or at least the Udyam Registration Number as evidence of MSME status. (2) Ageing analysis of payables – the company should maintain detailed accounts payable records showing invoice dates, acceptance/deemed acceptance dates and payment dates in order to determine which payments have exceeded the 45-day limit. (3) Internal controls – companies are expected to set up internal systems and cut-off procedures to capture all outstanding dues to MSEs as at 30 September and 31 March each year. (4) Updated MCA credentials – authorised signatories must possess valid DSCs and be registered users on the MCA V3 portal. For Udyam Annual Update: (1) Availability of the latest filed Income Tax Return and GST returns so that turnover and investment figures can be updated accurately; (2) correct Udyam Registration Number and access to the registered mobile number or Aadhaar-linked OTP for login; (3) clarity on current business status (e.g., any change in address, partners or directors) so that the portal profile can be updated in full. For AOC-4 and MGT-7: prerequisites include audited financial statements, board and shareholder approvals where required, and a clear record of shareholding and governance details; these are generic company law prerequisites rather than MSME-specific.
additionalInfo.recentUpdates: Several 2024–25 materials in the search results highlight recent developments relevant to MSME annual/periodic returns: (1) Enhanced MSME-1 format and MCA V3 migration (2025): TaxGuru’s October 2025 article on 'Form MSME-1: Filing, Due Dates, Applicability, Penalty & Payment Compliance', its October 2025 'MSME-1 V3 Era' article, and Tally Solutions’ June 2025 note on 'MSME Form 1 Reporting Changes' describe how MSME-1 has been upgraded on the MCA V3 portal. The new MSME-1 (V3) form requires more detailed information than earlier iterations, including comprehensive company details (CIN/FCRN, name, registered office address, email ID, PAN), explicit selection of the reporting half-year, and granular supplier-wise data (identification of each Micro or Small Enterprise supplier, Udyam Registration details, amount outstanding, exact date from which dues have been pending, and reasons for delay, together with flags relating to interest under the MSMED Act). These enhancements are aimed at strengthening oversight of delayed payments to MSMEs and enabling more robust analytics by regulators. (2) Continued emphasis on half-yearly due dates: Multiple 2025 articles (StartupFlora, SAG Infotech, LegalWiz, Bajaj Finserv, ClearTax, TaxGuru) reiterate and re-educate companies about the 31 October and 30 April due dates for MSME-1, indicating that regulators and practitioners consider delayed payment reporting a high-priority compliance area for 2025. (3) Clarifications on MSME financial data used for classification: The IndiaFilings article on 'MSME Clarification on Selection of Financial Year for Udyam Registration' explains that for determining MSME classification on the Udyam portal, the Ministry uses data from Income Tax and GSTN systems for a relevant financial year (for example, FY 2020–21 data for classification in 2022–23). This underscores that MSME classification is data-driven and somewhat lagged, and highlights the importance of accurate tax filings and periodic updates of Udyam details. (4) MSME sector profile and Udyam portal background: The official 'MSME Annual Report 2024-25' of the Ministry of MSME notes that the Udyam Registration portal was launched on 1 July 2020, replacing the earlier Udyog Aadhaar system, and it discusses the revised classification criteria based on both investment and turnover. The report also highlights the MSME sector’s contribution to India’s GDP and exports, reinforcing the policy focus on timely payments and data transparency, which in turn drives enforcement of MSME-1 and the need for up-to-date Udyam records. (5) Stronger enforcement narrative for MSME-1 penalties: News and guidance pieces such as TaxScan’s April 2025 article and CompanySuggestion’s July 2024 discussion of adjudication orders emphasise that companies can face significant penalties – including daily penalties and caps up to ₹3 lakh per defaulter – for non-filing of MSME-1, indicating that ROC adjudication in relation to MSME-1 is an active area in 2024–25. (6) Ongoing emphasis on general annual returns for MSME companies: TMWala’s 2025 compliance checklist and the IndiaFilings penalty article highlight that MSME companies must not only comply with MSME-1 and Udyam requirements but also remain current on general ROC forms AOC-4 and MGT-7/MGT-7A, where the effective additional fee for delayed filing (₹100 per form per day, described in IndiaFilings as ₹200 per day when both AOC-4 and MGT-7 are overdue) continues to apply in 2025.

msme-form-1.name: Form MSME-1 (Half-Yearly Return on Delayed Payments to Micro and Small Enterprise Suppliers)

applicability.condition: Form MSME-1 is a statutory disclosure under the Companies Act, 2013 that must be filed with the Registrar of Companies (ROC) by "specified companies" that delay payments to Micro and Small Enterprise (MSE) suppliers beyond 45 days. A "specified company" for this purpose is any company incorporated under the Companies Act, 2013 (or earlier Companies Acts), whether public or private and regardless of size or turnover, that (a) has procured goods or services from suppliers registered as Micro or Small Enterprises under the Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises Development Act, 2006 (MSMED Act) / Udyam Registration, and (b) where, for any such MSE supplier, the time taken to make payment from the date of acceptance or deemed acceptance of goods or services exceeds 45 days. Medium Enterprises are expressly excluded as suppliers for this particular reporting requirement – only Micro and Small Enterprises count as MSE suppliers for MSME-1. As clarified in 2024–2025 commentary and the 2025 notification (S.O. 1376(E) dated 25.03.2025), the return is triggered for a half-year if (1) any payment to an MSE supplier has at any point during that half-year remained unpaid for more than 45 days from the date of acceptance/deemed acceptance (even if fully paid before the period-end), or (2) as of the last day of the half-year, any amount remains outstanding to an MSE supplier for more than 45 days. The return is filed by the buying company (the debtor), not by the MSME supplier. There is no exemption based on company size, turnover, paid-up capital, or sector; applicability is purely based on (i) being a company and (ii) having delayed payments to registered Micro or Small Enterprises beyond 45 days.

threshold.description: The statutory trigger is time-based, not amount-based. Any invoice or payable to a registered Micro or Small Enterprise supplier that remains unpaid for more than 45 days from the date of acceptance or deemed acceptance of goods/services (as defined in the MSMED Act, 2006) is a "delayed payment". If at least one such delayed payment occurs in a half-year, or is still outstanding at the end of that half-year, the company becomes liable to file Form MSME-1 for that period. There is no minimum invoice value, aggregate dues threshold, turnover threshold, or capital threshold prescribed for triggering MSME-1.

exemptions: Entities that are not "companies" under the Companies Act, 2013 – such as LLPs, partnership firms, proprietorships, HUFs, societies and trusts – are not required to file Form MSME-1 (even though they must still comply with the MSMED Act 45-day payment rule).

Companies that have not procured any goods or services from suppliers registered as Micro or Small Enterprises under the MSMED Act / Udyam during a given half-year have no MSME-1 filing obligation for that period.

Companies that have procured from registered Micro or Small Enterprises but have ensured that all such payments were made within 45 days from the date of acceptance/deemed acceptance, so that no invoice ever crossed the 45-day limit during the half-year and there is no outstanding amount beyond 45 days on the half-year-end date, are not required to file MSME-1 for that half-year. (Note: 2024–2025 updates make it clear that if even a single invoice crosses 45 days at any time, a return is required, even if it is later cleared.)
Payments to Medium Enterprises (i.e., suppliers classified as "Medium" under the MSMED Act) are outside the ambit of MSME-1 reporting; only Micro and Small Enterprises are covered.
Payments to small vendors that are NOT registered as MSMEs (i.e., do not possess a valid Udyam Registration as Micro or Small) are not reportable in MSME-1, even if payment is delayed beyond 45 days.

For a specific half-year, if all outstanding dues to MSE suppliers have been paid within 45 days and there was no point during the period when any such dues crossed 45 days, no MSME-1 needs to be filed (that is, NIL return is not mandated where there has been no delayed payment at all).

forms.name: Form MSME-1 – Half-yearly return for delays in payments to Micro and Small Enterprises (October–March period)
forms.description: Form MSME-1 (also referred to as MSME Form I or MSME-1 (V3) on the MCA V3 portal) is an e-form prescribed under the Companies (Furnishing of information about payment to micro and small enterprise suppliers) Order, 2019, read with Section 405 of the Companies Act, 2013. It is used by specified companies to furnish a half-yearly return to the Registrar of Companies giving particulars of payments to registered Micro and Small Enterprise (MSE) suppliers that were delayed beyond 45 days from the date of acceptance/deemed acceptance of goods or services. This particular instance of the form covers the half-year reporting period from 1 October to 31 March (October–March). In the current revised regime (as reflected in 2024–2025 articles and the 2025 notification), the form must capture: (a) all dues to MSE suppliers that are outstanding for more than 45 days as of 31 March, and (b) all invoices to MSE suppliers where, at any time during the October–March period, the payment actually took more than 45 days from the date of acceptance/deemed acceptance, even if the dues were fully paid by 31 March. The form is not filed by the MSME itself; it is filed by the buying company (the debtor) and includes supplier-wise details such as the name of the MSE supplier, its PAN, amount due or delayed, the date from which it became due, and the reason for the delay. The e-form is filed through the MCA21 V3 portal and must be digitally signed by an authorised signatory (Director, CFO or Company Secretary).

deadline.formula: For the October–March half-year, Form MSME-1 must be filed on or before 30 April immediately following the end of that half-year. Thus, for the period 1 October 2024 to 31 March 2025, the due date is 30 April 2025; for 1 October 2025 to 31 March 2026, the due date is 30 April 2026, and so on.
deadline.calculation:
Step 1: Identify all transactions with registered Micro and Small Enterprise (MSE) suppliers for the six‑month period from 1 October to 31 March.
Step 2: For each invoice, determine the "date of acceptance" or "deemed acceptance" as per the MSMED Act, 2006 (typically, the date when the buyer accepts delivery or, if objections are not raised within 15 days, the date of delivery becomes deemed acceptance).
Step 3: Compute the number of days between the date of acceptance/deemed acceptance and the date of actual payment (or the 31 March cut‑off date if still unpaid). If this exceeds 45 days at any point, flag the invoice as a "delayed payment". Also separately identify invoices that remain unpaid beyond 45 days as of 31 March.
Step 4: Aggregate all such delayed payments to MSE suppliers and prepare supplier‑wise details: supplier name, PAN, amount due or delayed, the date from which the amount became due, and reasons for delay.
Step 5: Log in to the MCA21 V3 portal, select the Form MSME‑1 for the relevant October–March half‑year, enter company identification details (CIN/FCRN, name, registered office address, email ID, PAN, etc.) and reporting period details, and fill in the supplier‑wise delayed payment information.
Step 6: Get the form digitally signed by an authorised signatory (Director, CFO or Company Secretary with a valid Digital Signature Certificate), perform pre‑scrutiny/validation, and upload the e‑form. Filing must be completed by 30 April following the 31 March cut‑off date.
deadline.gracePeriod: There is no statutory grace period prescribed in the Order or the Companies Act for Form MSME-1. Even a one‑day delay beyond 30 April may technically attract penalty under Section 405(4). In practice, any relaxation of the deadline, if granted, is done by the Ministry of Corporate Affairs (MCA) through specific General Circulars or notifications for a particular year or event (for example, during extraordinary disruptions), and such relaxations are not automatic.
deadline.extensions: Guidance articles for FY 2025–26 report that the government/MCA has confirmed the MSME Form 1 due dates on the official MCA website for that year, continuing the pattern of 30 April (for October–March) and 31 October (for April–September). As per the snippets available, no permanent statutory extension has been introduced up to late 2025. Any year‑specific extensions, if notified by MCA, must be checked in the latest MCA General Circulars and notifications; they are not embedded in the core legal provision governing MSME‑1.

forms.penalty:
Penalties arise under two different laws: (1) the Companies Act, 2013 for non‑filing/incorrect filing of Form MSME‑1, and (2) the MSMED Act, 2006 for delayed payment to MSE suppliers itself.

A. Penalty under the Companies Act, 2013 (Section 405(4)) for MSME‑1 non‑compliance:
• Trigger: Failure to file the return in Form MSME‑1 by the due date, or furnishing information or statistics that are incorrect or incomplete in any material respect.
• Who is liable: The company as a legal entity, and every officer of the company who is in default.
• Base penalty: Commentaries summarising the current (post‑decriminalisation) Section 405(4) provision state that the company and each officer in default are liable to a fixed penalty of ₹20,000 for such failure.
• Per‑day penalty: Additional penalty of ₹1,000 per day for the period during which the default continues beyond the first day of default (i.e., from the day after the due date until the date of actual filing/rectification), as reported by professional platforms (e.g., one source explicitly mentions "penalty of Rs. 20,000" with an additional "fine of Rs. 1,000 per day of default").
• Maximum penalty (cap): At least one reported source notes that companies may face penalties "up to ₹3 lakh" for not filing MSME‑1; this aligns with the common cap structure in the Companies Act after the 2020 amendments, where total penalty for the company for a continuing default is generally capped at ₹3,00,000. Some earlier/alternate commentaries (including those quoting the pre‑amendment text) refer to a fine structure of up to ₹25,000 for the company and a range of ₹25,000 to ₹3,00,000 for every officer in default, or quote penalty ranges (e.g., ₹25,000 to ₹1,00,000). Because of these varying secondary sources, the exact officer‑level cap (e.g., ₹1,00,000 vs ₹3,00,000) should be confirmed from the latest bare text of Section 405(4) and any subsequent MCA amendments.
• Calculation method (company perspective, based on the common post‑amendment reading):
  – Step 1: Identify the number of days of continuous default: from the day after the statutory due date (e.g., 1 May for the October–March period) up to and including the actual date of filing or the date on which the ROC takes cognisance of non‑filing.
  – Step 2: Start with a fixed penalty of ₹20,000.
  – Step 3: Add ₹1,000 for each day of continuing default after the first day (i.e., number of days in Step 1).
  – Step 4: If the sum of the fixed penalty and daily penalties exceeds the statutory cap (commonly cited as ₹3,00,000 for the company), restrict the company’s total penalty to that cap.
  – Step 5: A similar computation is applied to each officer in default, subject to the individual caps applicable to officers (variously cited in commentaries as between ₹1,00,000 and ₹3,00,000). The adjudicating officer under the Companies Act has discretion within these bounds.
• Important nuances: (a) Penalty is adjudicated and imposed by the designated adjudicating officer; it is not an automatic “late fee” that is paid at the time of form upload. (b) Separate penalties may apply for each half‑year of default, since MSME‑1 is a half‑yearly return.

B. Financial consequence under MSMED Act, 2006 for delayed payments (independent of MSME‑1 filing):
• Trigger: Failure by a buyer (including companies) to make payment to a registered Micro or Small Enterprise supplier within the period agreed in writing (which cannot exceed 45 days from the date of acceptance or deemed acceptance), or, where no written agreement exists, within 15 days from the date of acceptance/deemed acceptance.
• Interest rate: The buyer is liable to pay compound interest with monthly rests at three times the bank rate notified by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI). This is a statutory obligation under Section 16 of the MSMED Act and cannot be contracted out of.
• Interest calculation method:
  – Step 1: Determine the "appointed day" as per MSMED Act (typically the day following the expiry of the maximum permitted credit period under Section 15, which in any case may not exceed 45 days from date of acceptance/deemed acceptance).
  – Step 2: Calculate the outstanding principal owed to the MSE supplier on each day of delay beyond the appointed day.
  – Step 3: Apply interest at 3 × RBI bank rate, with monthly compounding, on the outstanding principal from the appointed day until the date of actual payment.
• Enforcement: The MSE supplier may file a reference to the Micro and Small Enterprises Facilitation Council (MSEFC) via the MSME SAMADHAAN portal. As per the SAMADHAAN system description, every reference to MSEFC is to be decided within 90 days. Proceedings before MSEFC can result in enforceable orders for payment of principal plus statutory interest.
• Interaction with MSME‑1: Filing or non‑filing of MSME‑1 does not affect the supplier’s substantive right to interest under the MSMED Act. MSME‑1 is a disclosure/compliance requirement under the Companies Act; the interest obligation and potential MSEFC proceedings arise independently under the MSMED Act.

In practice, companies should treat MSME‑1 non‑filing risk as a layered consequence: (1) regulatory penalty under Section 405(4) (fixed plus per‑day penalty, subject to caps) and (2) commercial and legal exposure to MSEFC proceedings and statutory interest at three times the RBI bank rate for the underlying delayed payments.

forms.name: Form MSME-1 – Half-yearly return for delays in payments to Micro and Small Enterprises (April–September period)
forms.description: This is the same statutory Form MSME‑1 e‑form filed under Section 405 of the Companies Act, 2013 and the Companies (Furnishing of information about payment to micro and small enterprise suppliers) Order, 2019, but for the half‑year reporting period from 1 April to 30 September (April–September). The form is identical in structure to the October–March return; the reporting period is selected using the "Return / Reporting Period" or similar field in the MCA V3 e‑form interface. For the April–September half‑year, the company must disclose: (a) all amounts payable to registered Micro and Small Enterprise suppliers that remain outstanding for more than 45 days as of 30 September, and (b) all invoices where payment during that April–September period took more than 45 days from the date of acceptance/deemed acceptance, even if no amount is outstanding as on 30 September. Guidance sources emphasise that the filing obligation is triggered even if there is just a single delayed payment during the half‑year. The e‑form requires company details (CIN/FCRN, name, registered office address, email, PAN, etc.), selection of half‑year, and supplier‑wise information (name of MSE supplier, PAN, amount due/delayed, date from which it became due, and reason for delay), and it must be digitally signed by a Director, CFO or Company Secretary.

deadline.formula: For the April–September half-year, Form MSME-1 must be filed on or before 31 October immediately following the end of that half-year. For example, for the period 1 April 2025 to 30 September 2025, the due date is 31 October 2025 (this specific example is cited in recent guidance articles). This 31 October deadline recurs every year for the April–September reporting period.
deadline.calculation:
Step 1: Identify all transactions with registered Micro and Small Enterprise (MSE) suppliers between 1 April and 30 September of the relevant financial year.
Step 2: Determine the date of acceptance or deemed acceptance for each invoice as per MSMED Act provisions.
Step 3: For each invoice, compute the number of days taken from the date of acceptance/deemed acceptance to the actual date of payment (or to 30 September if unpaid). If this exceeds 45 days at any time during the period, mark it as a delayed payment. Also separately tag invoices that remain unpaid for more than 45 days as of 30 September.
Step 4: Compile supplier‑wise details of such delayed payments (names, PANs, amounts delayed/outstanding, date from which the amount became due, and reasons for delay).
Step 5: Log in to the MCA21 V3 portal, open the MSME‑1 e‑form for the April–September half‑year, and fill in company identification details, reporting period, and supplier‑wise delayed payment data.
Step 6: Have the e‑form digitally signed by an authorised signatory (Director, CFO or Company Secretary). Upload the form on MCA21 V3 so that the filing is completed on or before 31 October following the 30 September cut‑off date.
deadline.gracePeriod: There is no statutory grace period built into the MSME‑1 provisions; the due date is a hard cut‑off of 31 October for the April–September period. Any condonation or relaxation can only occur through specific MCA circulars or adjudication and is not automatic.
deadline.extensions: Recent 2025‑dated guidance notes that MCA has confirmed the regular half‑yearly due dates (31 October for April–September, 30 April for October–March) on its portal for FY 2025–26. No standing extension regime has been created; any extension must be checked for each year in the latest MCA notifications and circulars. There is no indication from the available snippets of any systemic extension of the April–September MSME‑1 deadline beyond 31 October.

forms.penalty:
The penalty framework for the April–September MSME‑1 is identical to that for the October–March MSME‑1, because both are governed by Section 405(4) of the Companies Act, 2013 and the same MSMED Act provisions on delayed payment. In summary:

A. Under the Companies Act, 2013 (Section 405(4)):
• Failure to file the April–September MSME‑1 by 31 October, or furnishing incorrect/incomplete information, exposes the company and every officer in default to a base penalty commonly summarised as ₹20,000, plus an additional ₹1,000 per day of continuing default after the due date, up to an overall cap (reported in guidance as up to ₹3,00,000 for the company). Older commentaries still quote a fine structure of up to ₹25,000 for the company and ₹25,000–₹3,00,000 (or up to ₹1,00,000) for officers. Users should confirm the exact current figures in the latest bare text of Section 405(4).
• Penalties are imposed via adjudication (they do not function as an automatic late fee on the MCA portal). Separate defaults for each half‑year may attract separate penalties.

B. Under the MSMED Act, 2006:
• The underlying delayed payments to MSE suppliers for the April–September period trigger statutory interest at three times the RBI bank rate, compounded monthly, from the appointed day until payment. Suppliers can invoke the MSME SAMADHAAN system and MSEFC for adjudication, which, as per official descriptions, is to be decided within 90 days of reference.

The practical computation steps and risk profile (base penalty, per‑day penalty, interest at 3× RBI bank rate) are the same as described for the October–March MSME‑1 return.
