additionalInfo.registration: There is no separate registration process to become liable for or to use Form MSME-1. Any company registered under the Companies Act, 2013 (or earlier Companies Acts) that meets the specified conditions is automatically a "specified company" for this purpose. However, to determine whether MSME-1 is applicable, companies must identify which of their suppliers are registered as Micro or Small Enterprises under the MSMED Act. In practice, this means obtaining and maintaining evidence of the supplier’s Udyam Registration (Udyam Registration Certificate or Udyam Registration Number) and ensuring that the supplier is actually classified as Micro or Small (Medium enterprises do not qualify for MSME-1 reporting). The company must also be registered on the MCA21 V3 portal with an active login and maintain valid Digital Signature Certificates (DSCs) for authorised signatories (Directors, CFO, Company Secretary) to file the e-form.
additionalInfo.renewal: There is no concept of renewal for Form MSME-1 itself; it is a recurring half-yearly return and must be filed separately for each half-year in which the trigger conditions are met. Suppliers’ Udyam registrations may require periodic verification/updates separately under MSME rules (e.g., annual update obligations for Udyam), but those are separate MSME-side compliances and do not replace or remove the buyer-company’s duty to file MSME-1.
additionalInfo.filingMethod: Form MSME-1 is filed exclusively online through the Ministry of Corporate Affairs’ MCA21 (V3) portal. The process typically involves: (1) Logging into the MCA V3 portal with the company’s credentials; (2) Accessing the MSME-1 e-form (often as a web-based or downloadable e-form on the V3 interface); (3) Entering basic company information – Corporate Identity Number (CIN) or Foreign Company Registration Number (FCRN), company name, registered office address, email ID, PAN, and details of the person responsible (Director/CFO/CS, with DIN or PAN as required); (4) Selecting the reporting period type (half-yearly) and specifying whether the return pertains to April–September or October–March; (5) Providing supplier-wise information for all registered Micro and Small Enterprise suppliers to whom payments have been delayed beyond 45 days, including supplier name, PAN, amount due or delayed, the date from which the amount became due, and reason for delay in payment; (6) Running pre-scrutiny/validation checks built into the V3 system; (7) Applying a valid Digital Signature Certificate (DSC) of an authorised signatory (Director, CFO or Company Secretary) to digitally sign the form; and (8) Uploading the e-form and, if applicable, paying any prescribed filing fee under the Companies (Registration Offices and Fees) Rules (many guidance sources state that MSME-1 typically has no ROC filing fee, but companies should verify the current fee table in the MCA Rules for the relevant year). No physical filing or paper submission is required.
additionalInfo.prerequisites: Key prerequisites for accurate MSME-1 compliance include: (1) Identifying MSE suppliers: Maintain an updated list of suppliers who are registered as Micro or Small Enterprises under the MSMED Act (via Udyam). Obtain copies of their Udyam Registration Certificates or at least their Udyam Registration Numbers and classification (Micro/Small), and review periodically; (2) Contract and invoice records: Maintain clear records of purchase orders, supply contracts, invoices, and delivery/acceptance documentation, so that the "date of acceptance" or "deemed acceptance" can be determined for each transaction; (3) Ageing analysis: Maintain an invoice-wise ageing report specifically for MSE suppliers, tracking days outstanding from the date of acceptance/deemed acceptance to payment, to identify invoices crossing the 45-day threshold; (4) Internal controls: Set up internal processes or system flags to identify whenever an invoice to an MSE supplier crosses 45 days, because even a single such instance in a half-year triggers MSME-1 filing; (5) Board/management oversight: It is good practice (and sometimes required by internal policies) to place a note before the Board or Audit Committee summarising MSE dues and MSME-1 filings; (6) Authorised signatories: Ensure that at least one Director, CFO, or Company Secretary has an active DIN/PAN record and a valid Digital Signature Certificate registered on the MCA portal for signing the e-form; (7) Reconciliation with MSMED obligations: Align MSME-1 data with the interest obligations and payments under the MSMED Act (including any claims through MSEFC/SAMADHAAN) so that disclosures are consistent.
additionalInfo.recentUpdates: Significant 2024–2025 developments affecting MSME-1 compliance from the available search results include: (1) Expanded trigger for filing: A 2024 expert analysis of the revised MSME-1 form notes a new proviso requiring that Form MSME-1 be furnished for a half-year if the company has made even a single delayed payment to any MSE supplier during that period, not only when amounts are outstanding beyond 45 days on the reporting date. A 2025 TaxGuru article on the "V3 era" of MSME-1 reinforces that if any payment exceeds 45 days even once, or remains pending beyond 45 days at the half-year end, MSME-1 filing becomes mandatory. This is a practical expansion from the earlier interpretation focusing primarily on outstanding dues as of 31 March or 30 September; (2) Notification S.O. 1376(E) dated 25.03.2025: A March 2025 notification (reported in legal commentary) clarifies that all companies that receive supplies from Micro and Small Enterprises and whose payments to such suppliers exceed 45 days must submit a half-yearly return to MCA. This consolidates and emphasises the obligation for all qualifying companies, regardless of size, and affirms the half-yearly nature of the return; (3) V3 portal and form changes: Several 2025 articles discuss the migration of MSME-1 to the MCA V3 portal and associated changes: the form now more clearly structures information into sections such as (a) Company Information (CIN/FCRN, name, registered office address, email ID, PAN), (b) Return/Reporting Period (type of return – half-yearly – and choice between April–September or October–March), and (c) detailed supplier-wise tables capturing overdue beyond 45 days, reasons for delay, etc. The requirement for digital signatures by a Director, CFO, or Company Secretary is reiterated; (4) Reinforced due dates: Multiple 2025 sources (including practical guides and examples) confirm that, for 2025 onwards, the due dates remain 31 October for the April–September half-year and 30 April for the October–March half-year, with specific illustration that the return for April–September 2025 must be filed by 31 October 2025. One guide notes that MCA has explicitly announced or confirmed the MSME Form 1 due dates for financial year 2025–26 on its official website; (5) Clarified scope of suppliers: A 2025 detailed article reiterates that medium enterprises are not covered under this reporting requirement – only Micro and Small Enterprises are to be considered as MSE suppliers for MSME-1. This is consistent with the language of the MSMED Act and the 2019 Order; (6) Penalty clarifications: Recent guidance articles continue to cite Section 405(4) as the basis for penalty on non-filing or incorrect filing of MSME-1. There is some divergence between sources – older ones cite fines up to ₹25,000 for the company and ₹25,000–₹3,00,000 (or up to ₹1,00,000) for officers, whereas more recent ones reflect the post-decriminalisation penalty structure with a fixed base penalty (₹20,000) and a per-day penalty (₹1,000) up to an overall cap (often cited as ₹3,00,000). Another 2025 news article highlights that companies may face penalties up to ₹3,00,000 for not filing MSME-1; (7) Distinction between filer and beneficiary: Updated guides stress that MSME-1 is not filed by the MSME units themselves; it is filed by buying companies that delay payments beyond 45 days. MSMEs seeking redress must use the MSME SAMADHAAN system to approach the MSE Facilitation Council, which is expected (per the official portal) to decide cases within 90 days; (8) Due date guides for 2025: 2025 due-date compilation resources classify MSME Form 1 as a half-yearly return, with last dates 30 April (for October–March) and 31 October (for April–September); they clearly distinguish this from other MSME-related compliances such as the MSME Udyam Annual Update, which is an MSME-side requirement rather than a companies’ disclosure; (9) Strengthened linkage to broader MSME policy: 2025 articles emphasize that compliance with the 45-day MSME payment rule is a regulatory requirement for all businesses, and that MSME-1 is one of several tools (alongside SAMADHAAN, income-tax disallowance rules introduced separately, etc.) being used by regulators to enforce timely payments to micro and small enterprises.

relatedCompliances.name: MSME Udyam Registration Annual Update
relatedCompliances.description: While not part of Form MSME-1, some due-date guides list the "MSME Udyam Annual Update" as a separate compliance. This is an obligation on MSME entities themselves (suppliers) to keep their Udyam Registration data updated on an annual or periodic basis. Accurate and up-to-date Udyam Registration is important for supplier recognition as a Micro or Small Enterprise; only such registered MSEs are eligible for the protections of the MSMED Act and are visible for MSME-1 reporting by buyer-companies.
relatedCompliances.relevanceToMSME1: Companies should ensure that suppliers shown as MSEs in their MSME-1 filings actually hold valid and updated Udyam Registrations. Incorrect classification (e.g., reporting a non-registered vendor as an MSE) can lead to inaccurate MSME-1 returns and potential non-compliance under Section 405(4).

relatedCompliances.name: MSME SAMADHAAN / MSEFC Reference
relatedCompliances.description: MSME SAMADHAAN is an official Government of India portal (samadhaan.msme.gov.in) through which Micro and Small Enterprises can file applications to the Micro and Small Enterprises Facilitation Council (MSEFC) for recovery of delayed payments and interest under the MSMED Act, 2006. As noted on the portal, every reference made to MSEFC should be decided within 90 days of its making. The MSEFC can order payment of principal plus statutory interest at three times the RBI bank rate with monthly rests.
relatedCompliances.relevanceToMSME1: MSME SAMADHAAN is not a filing portal for Form MSME-1; it is used by MSE suppliers to enforce payment. However, non-compliance with the 45-day payment rule that shows up in MSME-1 returns frequently overlaps with disputes raised on SAMADHAAN. The existence of a SAMADHAAN/MSEFC case does not remove the company’s obligation to file MSME-1; conversely, filing MSME-1 does not avoid any liability to pay interest or comply with MSEFC orders.

applicability.condition: Annual filing of an Income Tax Return (ITR) under the Income-tax Act, 1961 for income earned in a financial year (here FY 2024-25: 1 April 2024 to 31 March 2025), corresponding to Assessment Year (AY) 2025-26. Applies to all persons (individuals, Hindu Undivided Families (HUFs), firms including partnership firms other than LLPs, companies and other entities) whose total income is above the basic exemption limit or who are otherwise mandatorily required to file a return (for example, due to specified high-value transactions, claiming a refund, or having foreign assets/income), regardless of place of business or residence within India. For SMEs, this typically covers proprietors, partners in firms, and small firms having business or professional income who file ITR-3 or ITR-4 (Sugam), as well as their promoters who may file ITR-1 or ITR-2 for salary/other income.

threshold.note: From the search results: ITR-4 (Sugam) is available to resident individuals, HUFs and firms (other than LLPs) with total income not exceeding ₹50 lakh (₹5,000,000) and having presumptive business/professional income under sections 44AD, 44ADA or 44AE. For late filing fee u/s 234F, there is a lower cap of ₹1,000 where total income does not exceed ₹5 lakh (₹500,000), and a higher fee of ₹5,000 where income exceeds ₹5 lakh. General basic exemption limits (old vs new tax regime) and audit thresholds under section 44AB are relevant for determining audit status and therefore the applicable ITR due date, but are not explicitly detailed in the provided search snippets.

exemptions: Persons (primarily individuals) whose gross total income is below the basic exemption limit and who do not meet any of the specific mandatory-filing conditions (such as high-value deposits, foreign travel expenditure, etc.) are generally not required to file an Income Tax Return, though they may file voluntarily. This exemption is based on the Income-tax Act but is not explicitly spelt out in the search snippets.

Non-resident individuals, non-resident HUFs and LLPs are not eligible to file ITR-4 (Sugam) and must use other applicable ITR forms (such as ITR-3 or ITR-5) instead; this restriction on ITR-4 is explicitly referenced in the search results (ITR-4 for resident individual/HUF/firm other than LLP).

Entities that are not persons under the Income-tax Act (for example, certain foreign sovereigns or entities exempt under specific provisions) may be exempt from filing returns, depending on their status under the Act; such status-based exemptions are not detailed in the given search results.

For TDS/TCS statements (not the ITR itself), the search results indicate that from Assessment Year 2025-26, no penalty under section 271H will be levied merely for delay in filing TDS/TCS statements, although related late-fee provisions (such as section 234E) may still apply. This is a related but separate compliance from the ITR filing itself.

forms.name: ITR-1 (Sahaj) – Income Tax Return for Individuals Having Income from Salaries, One House Property and Other Sources (No Business/Professional Income)
forms.description: ITR-1 (Sahaj) is a simplified return form designed for resident individual taxpayers (not HUFs, not firms, not companies) whose total income does not exceed ₹50 lakh for the year and who have income primarily from salary/pension, one house property, and income from other sources (such as interest), with no income from business or profession and no income from capital gains. It is not to be used by individuals who are directors in a company, hold unlisted equity shares, have foreign assets/foreign income or agricultural income above specified limits. For SMEs, this form may be used by proprietors who have closed their business or by promoters who only draw salary and passive income and do not have business income in their personal capacity.

deadline.formula: For AY 2025-26 (income of FY 2024-25), the normal due date u/s 139(1) for non-audit individual taxpayers is 31 July 2025. A Press Information Bureau note dated 7 September 2025 states that this usual 31 July deadline has been extended to 15 September 2025 for non-audit cases including ITR-1 to ITR-4. The Income Tax Department's 'News & e-Campaigns' (latest-news page) further clarifies that for AY 2025-26, the due date for filing ITRs has been extended from 15 September 2025 to 16 September 2025. Therefore, the final extended due date for filing ITR-1 for AY 2025-26 is 16 September 2025.
deadline.calculation: Step 1: Identify the financial year of income (here FY 2024-25: 1 April 2024 to 31 March 2025). Step 2: Determine the corresponding assessment year, which is the immediately following year (AY 2025-26). Step 3: Check whether you are a non-audit case: individuals filing ITR-1 typically do not require a tax audit, so they fall in the non-audit category. Step 4: Under section 139(1), the statutory due date for non-audit individual taxpayers is normally 31 July of the assessment year (31 July 2025). Step 5: Apply the specific extensions notified for AY 2025-26: (a) extension from 31 July 2025 to 15 September 2025 for non-audit cases including ITR-1 to ITR-4 (as per PIB Press Note and supporting guidance articles); (b) further extension from 15 September 2025 to 16 September 2025 as per the 'News & e-Campaigns' page of the Income Tax portal dated 06 September 2025. Step 6: The effective last date without late fee or interest for delay (subject to tax already paid) is therefore 16 September 2025. Example: A salaried individual with only salary and bank interest income should file their ITR-1 for FY 2024-25 any time on or before 16 September 2025 to avoid 234F late fee and 234A interest (assuming full taxes are paid by then).
deadline.gracePeriod: There is no statutory grace period beyond the extended due date. Any return filed after 16 September 2025 for AY 2025-26 is treated as a belated return u/s 139(4) and is subject to late filing fee under section 234F and interest under section 234A on unpaid tax, as well as non-monetary consequences such as loss of carry-forward of certain losses and restriction of some deductions and exemptions.
deadline.extensions: The timeline for AY 2025-26 non-audit ITR-1 filers is as follows: (1) Original statutory due date u/s 139(1): 31 July 2025. (2) Extension announced in a Press Information Bureau note dated 7 September 2025, which states that the deadline for non-audit cases including ITR-1 to ITR-4 is 15 September 2025 (extended from the usual 31 July). (3) A clarification by the Income Tax Department on 15 September 2025 (via a Newsonair news item) stated that the last date remains 15 September 2025 as of that communication. (4) Subsequently, the official 'News & e-Campaigns' page of the e-filing portal (dated 06 September 2025 but reflecting the final extension) announced that the due date for filing ITRs for AY 2025-26 has been extended from 15 September 2025 to 16 September 2025. This 1-day extension is effectively the latest operative extension, making 16 September 2025 the final due date for non-audit ITR-1 filing for AY 2025-26.

forms.penalty: Monetary penalties and interest for late filing of ITR-1 for AY 2025-26 are as follows: (1) Late filing fee under section 234F: If the return is filed after the due date u/s 139(1) (here, after 16 September 2025) but on or before 31 March 2026, a late fee is levied as per official penalty charts and multiple guidance sources: (a) where total income does not exceed ₹5,00,000, the late filing fee is capped at ₹1,000; (b) where total income exceeds ₹5,00,000, the late filing fee is ₹5,000. Several sources (ClearTax, Angel One, Neeraj Bhagat & Co., and the official penalties chart on incometaxindia.gov.in) confirm that for AY 2025-26, the fee under section 234F is ₹1,000 or ₹5,000 depending on the ₹5 lakh income threshold, with maximum fee ₹5,000. (2) Interest under section 234A: If any self-assessment tax remains unpaid as on the original statutory due date (31 July 2025 for non-audit individuals) or as on the extended due date treated as the effective due date, interest at 1% per month or part of a month is payable on the unpaid tax amount from the due date until the date of actual filing/payment. Multiple sources (ClearTax late-tax-return article, Angel One penalty article, PIB note) explicitly mention a monthly 1% interest on pending tax for delayed filing. Example: If ₹20,000 of tax remains unpaid and the return is filed 3 months after the due date, interest under section 234A would be 1% × 3 months × ₹20,000 = ₹600 (months counted as full months for any part of a month). (3) Interest under sections 234B and 234C: If the taxpayer is liable to pay advance tax and either fails to pay it or pays less than 90% of assessed tax, interest u/s 234B at 1% per month on the shortfall from 1 April 2025 till date of payment is applicable. For shortfalls in individual advance tax instalments, interest u/s 234C at 1% per month on the shortfall in each instalment period applies; guidance sources (TOI article, EMSME article) note that each missed or short-paid instalment suffers interest at 1% per month on the shortfall, and each missed instalment is treated separately. (4) Non-monetary consequences mentioned in the official ITR-1 FAQ include: inability to carry forward certain losses (e.g., business losses, capital losses) if the return is filed after the due date, and certain deductions and exemptions (particularly many under Chapter VI-A and some incentive sections) may not be available if the return is belated. (5) Other penalties mentioned in guidance sources (like ranges of ₹10,000 to ₹1,00,000 under some sections, and fees under section 234E for TDS statements) are separate compliances and do not alter the standard 234F and 234A/234B/234C framework for late filing of ITR-1.

forms.name: ITR-2 – Income Tax Return for Individuals and HUFs Not Having Income from Profits and Gains of Business or Profession
forms.description: ITR-2 is applicable to individuals and Hindu Undivided Families (HUFs) who do not have income from profits and gains of business or profession. It is used when the taxpayer has income from salary/pension, more than one house property, capital gains (short-term or long-term), income from other sources (including interest, dividends, winnings etc.) and foreign income or foreign assets, but no business/professional income. Guidance sources explaining 'Which ITR to File' state that where a person does not have business or professional income, they should use ITR-2 instead of ITR-3 or ITR-4. For SMEs, this form is relevant for promoters or owners who hold investments or rental properties in their personal capacity but do not directly carry business through a proprietorship during the year.

deadline.formula: For AY 2025-26, the due date u/s 139(1) for non-audit cases (which includes ITR-2 filers because they do not have business/professional income requiring audit) follows the same pattern as ITR-1: normally 31 July of the assessment year (31 July 2025), extended for AY 2025-26 first to 15 September 2025 and then further to 16 September 2025 as per the Income Tax Department's 'News & e-Campaigns' announcement.
deadline.calculation: Step 1: Confirm that the taxpayer has no business or professional income; if yes, ITR-2 is generally applicable (subject to other conditions such as residency, source mix, etc.). Step 2: Determine financial year and assessment year as for ITR-1 (FY 2024-25 → AY 2025-26). Step 3: Identify that this is a non-audit case since section 44AB audit is generally not attracted in the absence of business/profession income. Step 4: Apply the same non-audit ITR due dates as for ITR-1, i.e., ordinary due date 31 July 2025 extended to 15 September 2025, and finally to 16 September 2025. Step 5: To stay compliant and avoid late fee and interest, ensure that the ITR-2 is filed electronically on the e-filing portal by 16 September 2025.
deadline.gracePeriod: No separate grace period beyond the notified extended due date. Returns filed after 16 September 2025 will be belated returns attracting 234F late fee and 234A interest (if tax is unpaid) and will face restrictions on loss carry-forward and some deductions/exemptions.
deadline.extensions: The same extensions as for ITR-1 apply: PIB Press Note shifting the normal due date from 31 July 2025 to 15 September 2025 for non-audit ITR-1 to ITR-4 filers, clarification by the Department on 15 September 2025 that the last date remains 15 September as of that statement, and a final extension to 16 September 2025 as per the Income Tax Department's 'latest-news' page on 06 September 2025.

forms.penalty: The penalty and interest regime applicable to late filing of ITR-2 is identical to that for ITR-1: (1) Section 234F late filing fee of up to ₹5,000, with a reduced maximum of ₹1,000 where total income does not exceed ₹5,00,000 (based on the official penalties chart and multiple guidance articles). (2) Section 234A interest at 1% per month or part of a month on unpaid tax from the due date (here effectively 16 September 2025 after extension) till the date of actual filing/payment. (3) Interest under sections 234B and 234C where there is a default or shortfall in payment of advance tax, calculated at 1% per month on the shortfall amounts for the relevant periods as per EMSME and TOI explanations. (4) Non-monetary consequences highlighted in the ITR-1 FAQ apply similarly: late filing leads to loss of ability to carry forward certain losses and disallowance of some deductions and exemptions. These consequences are relevant especially for ITR-2 filers who often have capital gains and other investment income where carry-forward of losses (e.g., capital losses) is important for tax planning.

forms.name: ITR-3 – Indian Income Tax Return for Individuals and HUFs Having Income from Profits and Gains of Business or Profession
forms.description: ITR-3 is the standard business/professional income return for individuals and Hindu Undivided Families (HUFs). The incometax.gov.in business/profession help page and multiple guidance articles state that ITR-3 is applicable for individuals and HUFs who earn income from profits and gains of business or profession (other than those eligible and choosing to use presumptive taxation via ITR-4). It can also include income from salary, house property, capital gains and other sources, but its key distinguishing feature is the presence of business/professional income computed on normal (non-presumptive) basis. For SMEs this covers proprietorship businesses, small professional practices, and HUF-run businesses that maintain books of account and may or may not be subject to tax audit under section 44AB. The official ITR-3 form PDF (formitr_3_2025.pdf) for AY 2025-26 also notes that where a taxpayer with business/professional income wants to exercise the option under section 115BAC(6) (opting out of or into the new tax regime), this must be done through Form 10IEA filed on or before the due date u/s 139(1).

deadline.formula: For AY 2025-26, ITR-3 due dates differ depending on whether the taxpayer is a non-audit case or a tax-audit case under section 44AB or similar provisions: (1) Non-audit ITR-3 cases (turnover/professional receipts below audit threshold and no mandatory audit requirement): these follow the same non-audit due date as ITR-1/2/4, which is ordinarily 31 July 2025 but extended via PIB Press Note and later Department announcements to 16 September 2025 for AY 2025-26. (2) Tax-audit ITR-3 cases (where accounts are required to be audited under section 44AB, or the assessee is a partner of a firm whose accounts are audited): the normal statutory due date u/s 139(1) is 31 October 2025. A CBDT Press Release dated 29 October 2025 and Circular No. 15/2025 extended the due date for furnishing the Return of Income for AY 2025-26 for these audit cases from 31 October 2025 to 10 December 2025. The Income Tax Department’s home page reflects this extension, stating that in view of Circular No. 15/2025 dated 29 October 2025, the due date has been extended to 10 December 2025.
deadline.calculation: Step 1: Determine whether the taxpayer falls under a mandatory tax audit category (for example, due to business turnover or professional receipts exceeding the thresholds prescribed under section 44AB). If yes, treat the case as 'audit'; otherwise 'non-audit'. Step 2: For non-audit ITR-3 filers: apply the non-audit timetable (original 31 July 2025 → extension to 15 September 2025 for non-audit ITR-1 to ITR-4 filers → final extension to 16 September 2025 per Income Tax portal latest-news). Therefore, the effective due date is 16 September 2025. Step 3: For audit ITR-3 filers: the ordinary statutory due date is 31 October 2025. As per the CBDT Press Release dated 29 October 2025 and Circular No. 15/2025, the deadline for filing the return of income for AY 2025-26 has been extended to 10 December 2025. Therefore, for an audited proprietorship or a partner of an audited firm, ITR-3 must be filed by 10 December 2025 to be within the due date u/s 139(1). Step 4: Form 10IEA for exercising the option under section 115BAC(6) must also be furnished on or before the due date under section 139(1) corresponding to the taxpayer’s category (16 September 2025 for non-audit cases, 10 December 2025 for audit cases). Example 1 (non-audit): A small trader with turnover below the audit threshold and not opting for presumptive taxation uses ITR-3 and must file by 16 September 2025. Example 2 (audit): A professional whose receipts exceed the audit threshold and who is required to get accounts audited under section 44AB must file ITR-3 by 10 December 2025 for AY 2025-26.
deadline.gracePeriod: There is no statutory grace period beyond the extended due dates. A return filed after 16 September 2025 (in non-audit cases) or after 10 December 2025 (in audit cases) is treated as a belated return u/s 139(4). Such belated filing will attract late fee u/s 234F and interest u/s 234A on unpaid tax. For audit cases, late filing may also affect the ability to file tax audit reports in time and can expose the assessee to audit-related penalties under separate provisions, though those are not detailed in the search results.
deadline.extensions: For AY 2025-26 ITR-3 filers: (1) Non-audit: the due date was extended from 31 July 2025 to 15 September 2025 (PIB Press Note specifying that non-audit cases including ITR-1 to ITR-4 fall under this extension) and further extended to 16 September 2025 as per the e-filing portal's 'News & e-Campaigns' update dated 06 September 2025. (2) Audit: Circular No. 15/2025 dated 29 October 2025 formally extended the due date for furnishing returns of income (for cases where the original due date was 31 October 2025) to 10 December 2025. The Income Tax Department’s homepage and an associated press release (Press-Release-CBDT-extends-due-date-for-furnishing-Return-of-Income-for-the-Assessment-Year-2025-26-dated-29-10-2025.pdf) clearly state that the due date for AY 2025-26 audit cases is extended from 31 October 2025 to 10 December 2025.

forms.penalty: For ITR-3, the same late filing fee and interest provisions apply as for other ITRs, but business taxpayers must be particularly attentive because (1) they are more likely to have advance tax obligations, and (2) many rely on loss set-off/carry-forward and deductions which can be lost if returns are belated. The penalty structure, based on official and guidance sources, is: (1) Section 234F late filing fee: If ITR-3 is filed after the applicable due date u/s 139(1) (16 September 2025 for non-audit or 10 December 2025 for audit) but before 31 March 2026, the assessee must pay: (a) ₹1,000 where total income does not exceed ₹5,00,000, or (b) ₹5,000 where total income exceeds ₹5,00,000. This is explicitly reflected in the incometaxindia.gov.in penalties chart and multiple AY 2025-26 penalty explanations (Angel One, TOI, Neeraj Bhagat). The maximum late fee for AY 2025-26 as per these sources is ₹5,000. (2) Section 234A interest: Late filing when tax is unpaid as of the due date triggers interest at 1% per month or part of a month on the unpaid tax amount from the due date until the date of filing/payment. PIB and several private portals emphasize that this 1% per month interest is in addition to the 234F late fee. Example: If a business proprietor owes ₹100,000 in self-assessment tax as of 16 September 2025 but files and pays only on 20 December 2025 (roughly 3 full months delayed after due date), interest u/s 234A would be approximately 1% × 3 × ₹100,000 = ₹3,000, plus the applicable 234F fee. (3) Sections 234B and 234C interest for advance tax: Business taxpayers are more likely to meet advance tax criteria. TOI and EMSME sources state that late or short payment of advance tax attracts interest up to 1% per month on the shortfall: under section 234B for failure to pay at least 90% of assessed tax as advance tax, interest at 1% per month on the shortfall from 1 April 2025 until payment; under section 234C for shortfall in each advance tax instalment, interest at 1% per month (for the specified number of months per instalment) on the shortfall in each instalment, with each instalment treated separately. (4) Non-monetary implications indicated in the ITR-1 FAQ apply to ITR-3 as well: belated ITR-3 filing may prevent the assessee from carrying forward business losses and certain other losses, and can block some deductions and tax incentives (e.g., several profit-linked deductions requiring timely filing). (5) Separate penalties and fees mentioned in search results (sections 234E and 234G for defaults in TDS/TCS statements and research/donation-related statements, and 271H penalty waivers for delayed TDS/TCS statements effective AY 2025-26) do not directly relate to late filing of ITR-3 but may impact SMEs that are required to deduct tax at source; these are separate from the 234F and 234A/B/C framework affecting the ITR itself.

forms.name: ITR-4 (Sugam) – Income Tax Return for Resident Individuals, HUFs and Firms (Other Than LLPs) With Presumptive Business/Professional Income up to ₹50 Lakh
forms.description: ITR-4 (Sugam) is a simplified return form designed for small taxpayers opting for presumptive taxation. As per incometax.gov.in ITR-4 FAQs and the official ITR-4 form (itr4_english.pdf) for AY 2025-26, ITR-4 can be used by a resident individual, resident HUF, or firm (other than LLP) whose total income does not exceed ₹50 lakh (₹5,000,000) and who has business income computed under sections 44AD (presumptive income for eligible businesses), 44ADA (presumptive income for specified professions) or 44AE (presumptive income for transporters owning not more than the specified number of goods carriages), along with permissible income from salary/pension, one house property and other sources. It is not available to non-residents, LLPs, or persons with certain types of income such as income from more than one house property, capital gains, speculative business, agricultural income above certain limits, or foreign assets/foreign income. For SMEs, this is the primary form for small proprietorships and partnership firms (other than LLPs) that choose to compute profit as a fixed percentage of turnover or gross receipts under the presumptive schemes.

deadline.formula: The ITR-4 FAQ on incometax.gov.in states that for AY 2025-26 (FY 2024-25), the due date of filing ITR-4 is 15 September 2025. This reflects the initial extension from the normal 31 July 2025 date. However, the Income Tax Department's latest-news page later extended the due date for filing ITRs for AY 2025-26 from 15 September 2025 to 16 September 2025, which applies to all non-audit ITR filers including ITR-4. Therefore, the final extended due date for ITR-4 for non-audit presumptive taxpayers is 16 September 2025.
deadline.calculation: Step 1: Confirm eligibility for ITR-4: the taxpayer must be a resident individual, resident HUF or firm (not LLP), with total income up to ₹50 lakh and eligible presumptive business/professional income under sections 44AD/44ADA/44AE, and must not fall in any excluded category (for example, non-resident status, presence of capital gains or multiple house properties etc.). Step 2: Determine that such tax cases are typically non-audit under the Income-tax Act, as presumptive provisions generally exempt the assessee from maintaining detailed books and tax audit (subject to certain exceptions, such as voluntarily declaring profits lower than the presumptive rate while exceeding specified turnover limits). Step 3: Take the standard non-audit due date for AY 2025-26, which is 31 July 2025, and apply the published extensions: the PIB note and ITR-4 FAQ confirm an extension to 15 September 2025; the latest-news page then confirms a further extension to 16 September 2025. Step 4: Use 16 September 2025 as the effective last date to file ITR-4 without late fee and interest for delay (assuming taxes are already fully paid).
deadline.gracePeriod: No formal grace period exists beyond the extended date. Filing ITR-4 after 16 September 2025 means the return is belated u/s 139(4), with 234F late fee and 234A interest on any unpaid tax, and collateral consequences such as loss of carry forward of certain losses and some deduction restrictions.
deadline.extensions: The official extension trail for ITR-4 for AY 2025-26 is: (1) Normal non-audit due date: 31 July 2025. (2) Press Information Bureau note dated 7 September 2025 clarifying that for non-audit cases including filers under ITR-1 to ITR-4, the deadline has been extended from 31 July 2025 to 15 September 2025. (3) Incometax.gov.in ITR-4 FAQ updated to state that the due date for filing ITR-4 for AY 2025-26 is 15 September 2025. (4) Income Tax Department latest-news page (News & e-Campaigns) announcing that the due date for filing ITRs for AY 2025-26 has been further extended from 15 September 2025 to 16 September 2025. The ITR-4 FAQ text may not yet reflect this final 1-day extension, but the latest-news page and several guidance sites (ClearTax, Bajaj Finserv) confirm the operative last date as 16 September 2025.

forms.penalty: ITR-4 filers are subject to the same late filing fee and interest rules as other individual/HUF/firm taxpayers: (1) Late filing fee u/s 234F: For AY 2025-26, the late fee for filing ITR-4 after the due date (16 September 2025) is: ₹1,000 if total income is up to ₹5,00,000; ₹5,000 if total income exceeds ₹5,00,000. These thresholds and amounts are explicitly cited in the incometaxindia.gov.in penalties chart (which states that when total income is up to ₹5 lakh, the late filing fees is ₹1,000) and in multiple private guidance articles (Neeraj Bhagat, Angel One, TOI, ClearTax). Maximum late fee is therefore ₹5,000 for AY 2025-26. (2) Section 234A interest: Late filing where tax remains unpaid as of the due date triggers 1% per month (or part) interest on the unpaid tax from the due date (16 September 2025 after taking into account the extension) until the date of actual filing and payment. PIB and guidance sources stress that this is 1% per month on the pending tax amount in addition to the 234F fee. (3) Sections 234B and 234C: Even though presumptive taxpayers often pay much of their tax as self-assessment in a lump sum, they can still be liable to advance tax, and default or deferment triggers interest u/s 234B and 234C at 1% per month on the shortfall during prescribed periods, as described in EMSME and TOI articles. (4) Non-filing or late filing also results in the loss of certain tax planning benefits: the official ITR-1 FAQ mentions that a delay in filing returns may prevent the carry-forward of eligible losses and make some deductions and exemptions unavailable; this applies to ITR-4 as well. (5) Other penalty/fee provisions mentioned in the search results, like section 234E (late fee of ₹200 per day for delay in furnishing TDS/TCS statements), section 234G (fee for default in submission of statements/certificates under sections 35 and 80G), and penalty ranges of ₹10,000 to ₹1,00,000 under other sections discussed in some private articles, relate to other compliances (TDS/TCS or certificates) and not to the ITR-4 filing itself, and therefore are separate from the 234F and 234A/B/C framework for ITR-4.

forms.name: Form 10IEA – Form for Exercising Option under Section 115BAC(6) (Choice of New vs Old Tax Regime for Business/Professional Income Cases)
forms.description: Form 10IEA is a separate form referenced in the official ITR-3 form for AY 2025-26. The ITR-3 PDF clearly includes a note that the option under section 115BAC(6) (which allows eligible individuals and HUFs with business/professional income to opt out of the default new tax regime or exercise an option with respect to the regime) should be exercised in Form 10IEA on or before the due date for filing the return under section 139(1). This form is applicable primarily to individuals and HUFs who have income from business or profession and want to choose or change their tax regime (old vs new) in accordance with section 115BAC. For SMEs, this is crucial for proprietors and HUF businesses filing ITR-3 or potentially ITR-4 who need to formally notify the tax department of their regime choice.

deadline.formula: Form 10IEA must be furnished on or before the due date for filing the Income Tax Return u/s 139(1) applicable to the assessee. The ITR-3 form explicitly states that the option under section 115BAC(6) should be exercised in Form 10IEA on or before the due date for filing the return under section 139(1). Thus, for AY 2025-26: (1) Non-audit business/professional cases (e.g., small proprietors using ITR-3 but not under audit): due date for Form 10IEA is aligned to their ITR-3 due date of 16 September 2025. (2) Audit cases (e.g., ITR-3 filers whose accounts are audited under section 44AB): due date for Form 10IEA is aligned to their extended audit-case ITR-3 due date of 10 December 2025.
deadline.calculation: Step 1: Determine whether the taxpayer has income from business or profession and is eligible to exercise the option under section 115BAC(6). Step 2: Determine whether the case is audit or non-audit and identify the applicable due date under section 139(1) for the relevant ITR (16 September 2025 for non-audit, 10 December 2025 for audit in AY 2025-26). Step 3: Ensure that Form 10IEA is e-filed on the portal on or before that due date. Failing to file Form 10IEA within this timeline generally results in the taxpayer being treated as having not validly exercised the option, causing default treatment under the default tax regime prescribed under section 115BAC. Example: A resident individual proprietor with business income who wishes to continue under the old tax regime for AY 2025-26 and is a non-audit case must submit Form 10IEA online by 16 September 2025, along with or before filing ITR-3.
deadline.gracePeriod: There is no separate statutory grace period for filing Form 10IEA beyond the due date u/s 139(1). If Form 10IEA is not furnished by the applicable due date, the option under section 115BAC(6) may not be available for that year, and the taxpayer may be forced into the default regime as per the law.
deadline.extensions: Form 10IEA’s deadline automatically benefits from the same extensions as the ITR due dates, because the ITR-3 note ties its deadline explicitly to the ITR due date u/s 139(1). Therefore, for AY 2025-26: (1) non-audit cases benefit from the extension of the due date from 31 July 2025 to 15 September 2025 (PIB) and then to 16 September 2025 (e-filing portal news); (2) audit cases benefit from the extension from 31 October 2025 to 10 December 2025 through CBDT Circular No. 15/2025.

forms.penalty: There is no specific late fee amount prescribed in the search results for delayed filing of Form 10IEA itself. The primary consequence of failing to file Form 10IEA by the due date u/s 139(1) is that the taxpayer is treated as not having validly exercised the option under section 115BAC(6). As a result, they may be locked into the default tax regime (currently the new regime for many individuals) and may not be able to claim deductions and exemptions that are only available in the old regime, which can increase their tax liability. This is a substantive tax consequence rather than a separate monetary penalty or late fee. However, because Form 10IEA must accompany or precede timely filing of the ITR, a delay that also causes delayed ITR filing will attract the usual 234F late filing fee and 234A/234B/234C interest applicable to the ITR.
