additionalInfo.registration: To file an Income Tax Return electronically, the taxpayer must have a valid Permanent Account Number (PAN) and be registered on the Income Tax Department’s e-filing portal (incometax.gov.in). For individuals, linking PAN with Aadhaar is mandatory in most cases. SMEs operating as firms or proprietorships must ensure that both the entity (if applicable) and the key individual(s) have PANs. On first use, the taxpayer must create an e-filing account using PAN, validate contact details and secure login credentials. For some categories (e.g., companies, firms subject to audit), a Digital Signature Certificate (DSC) is required to sign the ITR electronically; others may use Electronic Verification Code (EVC) methods such as Aadhaar OTP, pre-validated bank account or demat account. The help page for salaried individuals refers to helplines (1800 103 0025, 1800 419 0025 and +91-80-46122000) available typically during working hours (around 08:00 to 20:00 Monday to Friday) to assist with e-filing of ITRs and forms.
additionalInfo.renewal: There is no periodic renewal of registration for ITR filing in the way that licenses renew; PAN is permanent. However, each assessment year requires a fresh ITR to be filed (annual compliance). Registration details on the e-filing portal (such as contact details, bank accounts for refund, and profile information) should be reviewed and updated periodically, but there is no separate renewal procedure mandated in the search results.
additionalInfo.filingMethod: Filing of Income Tax Returns is predominantly electronic. Taxpayers (including SMEs and their owners) can file online through the Income Tax Department e-filing portal (http://www.incometax.gov.in/iec/foportal/). Forms ITR-1, ITR-2, ITR-3 and ITR-4 can be filed: (1) Online directly in the browser using pre-filled data and step-wise wizards on the portal; or (2) Offline by downloading the Common Offline Utility (as referenced in the Downloads page – a ZIP utility of about 30.1 MB, version 1.2.5 for AY 2025-26), preparing the return in the utility and then generating and uploading a JSON file to the portal. For most taxpayers, physical (paper) filing is no longer permitted except in limited cases not detailed in the search results (such as very senior citizens meeting specific criteria). After electronic submission, the return must be verified (e-verified) via Aadhaar OTP, pre-validated bank/demat account, Digital Signature Certificate (DSC) or other approved EVC methods within the prescribed time to be treated as validly filed.
additionalInfo.prerequisites: Key prerequisites for compliant ITR filing for SMEs and individuals include: (1) Valid PAN for the taxpayer and, where applicable, TAN for TDS-related compliances; (2) Aadhaar-PAN linkage for individuals; (3) Registration on the e-filing portal with up-to-date contact information and bank account details (for refunds); (4) Maintenance of necessary books of account and records, especially for ITR-3 business/professional cases and for those potentially subject to audit under section 44AB; (5) Computation of total income including all heads (salary, house property, business/profession, capital gains, other sources) with segregation of presumptive vs non-presumptive income where relevant; (6) Determination and payment of advance tax where applicable to avoid or reduce interest under sections 234B and 234C (as highlighted in EMSME and TOI articles, which explain that interest at 1% per month applies on shortfalls for each unpaid or underpaid instalment, treating each instalment separately); (7) Payment of self-assessment tax before filing to minimize 234A interest; (8) For those intending to opt into or out of the new tax regime under section 115BAC(6), preparation and e-filing of Form 10IEA on or before the ITR due date (explicitly required in the ITR-3 form for AY 2025-26); and (9) For entities required to deduct tax at source (TDS/TCS), timely deposit of TDS/TCS (e.g., the Tax Calendar notes that TDS/TCS collected/deducted in October 2025 is generally due for deposit by 7 November 2025) and timely filing of TDS/TCS statements to avoid associated late fees under section 234E, even though penalties under section 271H for delay in TDS/TCS statements have been relaxed from AY 2025-26 as per the incometaxindia.gov.in penalty tutorial.
additionalInfo.recentUpdates: The 2025-related updates and changes captured in the search results that are relevant to ITR compliance for AY 2025-26 (FY 2024-25) include: (1) Extension of non-audit ITR due date: The usual due date of 31 July 2025 for non-audit taxpayers (including individuals filing ITR-1 to ITR-4) was extended to 15 September 2025 as per a Press Information Bureau note dated 7 September 2025 titled '15 September 2025: ITR Deadline – What Every Taxpayer Should Know', which clarifies that the extension is for non-audit cases including filers under ITR-1 to ITR-4. Subsequently, an official update on the Income Tax Department’s 'News & e-Campaigns' page announced that the due date for filing ITRs for AY 2025-26 has been extended from 15 September 2025 to 16 September 2025. Some communications (such as the Newsonair item on 15 September 2025) initially reiterated 15 September as the last date, but the later portal update prevails, making 16 September 2025 the final due date for non-audit ITR-1 to ITR-4 filers. (2) Clarification on audit-case ITR due date: For cases where the original statutory due date was 31 October 2025 (generally taxpayers whose accounts are required to be audited under section 44AB or partners of such firms filing ITR-3 or other relevant forms), CBDT issued Circular No. 15/2025 dated 29 October 2025 and a press release extending the due date for furnishing the Return of Income for AY 2025-26 from 31 October 2025 to 10 December 2025. The Income Tax Department home page explicitly references this extension. (3) Form updates for AY 2025-26: New versions of ITR-3 and ITR-4 forms were notified for AY 2025-26 (e.g., the ITR-3 form PDF dated 1 May 2025 and the ITR-4 English PDF). Articles such as 'Key Updates to ITR Forms for AY 2025-26' on India Briefing summarize functional changes (though detailed changes are not fully visible in the snippets), and the ITR-3 form now clearly references Form 10IEA for exercising the 115BAC(6) option. (4) Introduction/Use of Form 10IEA: The ITR-3 form specifically instructs that the option under section 115BAC(6) must be exercised in Form 10IEA on or before the due date for filing the return u/s 139(1), highlighting this form as a key compliance requirement for individuals and HUFs with business/professional income choosing between the new and old tax regimes. (5) Offline utility release for AY 2025-26: The Income Tax Department’s Downloads page indicates that a Common Offline Utility (ZIP, version 1.2.5, ~30.1 MB) is available for filing ITR-1, ITR-2, ITR-3 and ITR-4 for AY 2025-26, enabling offline preparation and JSON upload. (6) Clarifications and campaigns: The Department has used official channels (PIB, Newsonair, News & e-Campaigns) to clarify due dates and discourage reliance on unverified social media rumors about extensions, emphasizing that taxpayers should refer to official notifications. (7) Penalty regime commentary: Multiple 2025-dated guidance pieces reiterate that for AY 2025-26, late filing of ITRs attracts a fee under section 234F of ₹1,000 or ₹5,000 (depending on whether total income is up to or above ₹5 lakh) and interest at 1% per month on unpaid tax under section 234A, as well as interest under sections 234B and 234C for default/deferment of advance tax. (8) Change in TDS/TCS penalty: The incometaxindia.gov.in tutorial on 'Late Filing Fees and Penalty' notes that with effect from Assessment Year 2025-26, no penalty under section 271H will be levied merely in case of delay in filing TDS/TCS statements, although late fee u/s 234E still applies. While this change pertains to TDS/TCS statement filing rather than the main ITR, it is a noteworthy 2025 compliance relaxation for SMEs that deduct TDS. Overall, the 2025 cycle emphasizes timely ITR e-filing using updated forms and utilities, careful attention to extended but final due dates (16 September 2025 for non-audit and 10 December 2025 for audit cases for AY 2025-26), and the proper exercise of tax-regime options via Form 10IEA for business/professional taxpayers.

tax-audit.name: Income Tax Audit under Section 44AB and related audit report filing (Forms 3CA/3CB-3CD) for SMEs in India

applicability.condition: Tax audit in India refers to the mandatory audit of accounts under section 44AB of the Income-tax Act, 1961. It applies to persons carrying on business or profession (including individuals, HUFs, partnership firms, LLPs, companies and other entities) when specified turnover/gross receipt and other conditions are met. Based on the search results for AY 2025-26 (FY 2024-25) and general section 44AB rules as cited, the principal conditions are: (1) Businesses: A taxpayer carrying on business must get accounts audited if total sales/turnover/gross receipts exceed ₹1 crore in a financial year (as stated in multiple articles including ClearTax section 44AB, Bajaj Finserv, Tax2Win, EFileTax, Suvit and others). If the aggregate of cash receipts and cash payments does not exceed 5% of total receipts and payments (meaning at least 95% transactions are digital/non-cash), the turnover threshold for tax audit increases to ₹10 crore in that financial year (ClearTax 44AB, KDKSoftware, Tax2Win, TheLegalSchool and EFileTax snippets). EFileTax summarizes this as: if turnover exceeds ₹1 crore or if digital payments are less than 95% (i.e., cash transactions above 5%), tax audit becomes applicable. (2) Professionals: A taxpayer carrying on a specified profession must get accounts audited if gross receipts exceed ₹50 lakh in a financial year, as highlighted for section 44AB(b) in TheLegalSchool and Suvit articles. (3) Presumptive business (section 44AD): TaxGuru and related articles (AY 2024-25 focus) state that if business turnover does not exceed ₹2 crore and the taxpayer declares 6% or 8% of turnover as income under the presumptive scheme, no tax audit is required. However, if the taxpayer declares income lower than the presumptive rate and total income exceeds the basic exemption limit, a tax audit under section 44AB becomes mandatory. (4) Business loss: Bajaj Finserv’s 44AB explainer notes that even in case of business loss, if the turnover exceeds ₹1 crore, tax audit is applicable. In practice this interacts with presumptive schemes and the basic exemption limit (a business reporting loss or profit below presumptive norms with total income above the exemption threshold is typically brought into tax audit). (5) Statutory audit under other law: Entities already required to have their accounts audited under another law (e.g., Companies Act for companies, LLP Act, co-operative societies etc.) are still required to obtain tax audit under section 44AB if the monetary thresholds are crossed. For such entities, Form 3CA is used, which refers to and attaches the statutory audit report (ClearTax article on Forms 3CA, 3CB, 3CD, 3CE; eBizFiling article on tax audit for private limited companies). (6) Measurement base: The ICMAI supplementary paper on Tax Audit notes that applicability depends on 'sales', 'turnover' or 'gross receipts' but the Act itself does not define these terms, and practitioners rely on guidance notes/standards for interpretation. Tax audit applies on a PAN-based, per-assessee basis for each business/profession, consolidated across that assessee’s operations.

business.cashDigitalCriterionExplanation: Where aggregate of cash receipts and cash payments in the financial year does not exceed 5% of total receipts and total payments respectively (i.e., at least 95% are non-cash/digital), the threshold for mandatory tax audit is lifted from ₹1 crore (₹10,000,000) to ₹10 crore (₹100,000,000), as explicitly described in ClearTax’s section 44AB article, KDKSoftware’s applicability note, Tax2Win’s guide and TheLegalSchool/EFileTax discussions. If this 5% condition is not satisfied (i.e., if digital payments are less than 95%), the lower ₹1 crore turnover threshold continues to apply.

profession.explanation: For assessees carrying on a profession covered by section 44AB(b), tax audit becomes mandatory when gross receipts from the profession exceed ₹50 lakh (₹5,000,000) in a financial year, as stated in TheLegalSchool’s 44AB blog and Suvit’s article on tax audit limit for AY 2025-26.

presumptiveSection44ADBusiness.explanation: TaxGuru’s article on audit criteria for business & profession (AY 2024-25) states that where turnover does not exceed ₹2 crore (₹20,000,000) and the taxpayer opts for presumptive taxation under section 44AD declaring 6% (for eligible digital receipts) or 8% (for other receipts) of turnover as income, no tax audit is required. However, if the taxpayer declares income lower than these presumptive rates and the resulting total income exceeds the basic exemption limit, section 44AB tax audit becomes applicable even if turnover is within ₹2 crore.

lossCasesAndOthers.businessLossWithHighTurnover: Bajaj Finserv’s section 44AB explainer clarifies that even in case of a business loss, if turnover exceeds ₹1 crore, tax audit obligations arise. Combined with the basic exemption limit rules and presumptive provisions, this means a loss or low-profit business above threshold turnover may have to undergo tax audit.
lossCasesAndOthers.noteOnUndefinedTerms: The ICMAI paper emphasises that although section 44AB hinges on 'sales', 'turnover' or 'gross receipts', these terms are not defined in the Act and require reliance on professional guidance for computation, especially for mixed business/professional activities.

exemptions: Persons not carrying on any business or profession (for example, salaried individuals with only salary and interest income) are outside section 44AB and have no tax audit requirement, though they may have other audit or filing obligations.

Businesses with total sales/turnover/gross receipts not exceeding ₹1 crore in a financial year, and not otherwise caught by specific presumptive or loss provisions, are generally exempt from tax audit.

Businesses whose cash receipts and cash payments are each at or below 5% of total receipts and payments respectively, and whose turnover does not exceed ₹10 crore, are exempt from tax audit (per ClearTax 44AB, KDKSoftware, Tax2Win and EFileTax explanations).

Specified professionals with gross receipts not exceeding ₹50 lakh in a financial year are exempt from tax audit under section 44AB(b), though they may opt for presumptive profession schemes separately.

Businesses that qualify for and validly opt for presumptive taxation under section 44AD, with turnover not exceeding ₹2 crore and income declared at the prescribed presumptive rates (6%/8% of turnover), are exempt from tax audit for that year as long as they do not report lower profits with taxable income above the basic exemption limit.

Cases where the assessee was technically required to obtain a tax audit but failed to do so may still escape penalty under section 271B if they can demonstrate 'reasonable cause' for the failure under section 273B; this does not remove the legal obligation but can mitigate penalties (this reasonable-cause relief is referred to indirectly in eBizFiling’s 'Relief is ...' note on penalties and is part of the standard penalty regime).

There are no state-specific exemptions or variations for tax audit; the regime is fully governed by the central Income-tax Act and CBDT circulars and applies uniformly across all Indian states and union territories.

forms.name: Form 3CA with Form 3CD (Tax Audit Report for assessees whose accounts are already audited under another law)
forms.description: Form 3CA is the audit report format prescribed under section 44AB read with Rule 6G(1)(a) for assessees whose accounts are already required to be audited under any other law (such as companies under the Companies Act, LLPs under the LLP Act, certain co-operative societies, etc.). The form summarizes the auditor’s opinion for tax purposes and makes reference to the existing statutory audit report. Form 3CD is a detailed 'Statement of particulars required to be furnished under section 44AB', listing numerous clauses (PDICAI notes reference 35 reporting points for the 3CA–3CD combination) requiring disclosure of quantitative and qualitative particulars such as nature of business, details of depreciation, disallowable expenses, compliance with TDS/TCS provisions, particulars of loans/deposits, related-party transactions, and other specific reporting. For entities like private limited companies, eBizFiling’s 2025 article clarifies that tax audit is in addition to the mandatory statutory company audit and is reported through Form 3CA-3CD. Forms 3CA and 3CD are e-filed together by a Chartered Accountant (CA) via the Income Tax e-Filing portal, and then accepted electronically by the assessee.

deadline.formula: Standard rule: 30 September of the assessment year (AY) immediately following the relevant financial year (FY). That is, the audit report in Form 3CA-3CD must be obtained and furnished by the statutory due date for filing the income-tax return under section 139(1) for assessees covered by section 44AB, which is normally 30 September of the AY.
deadline.calculation: Identify the financial year (FY) for which the audit is required (for example, FY 2024-25 runs from 1 April 2024 to 31 March 2025). Determine the corresponding assessment year (AY), which is the year immediately following the FY (for FY 2024-25, the AY is 2025-26). Under the FAQs on Tax Audit at incometaxindia.gov.in, the assessee must get the accounts audited and obtain the audit report on or before 30 September of the relevant assessment year. Thus, for FY 2024-25, the statutory base due date is 30 September 2025. The same timeline applies both for 'obtaining' the report from the CA and for e-filing the report on the portal. The CA uploads Form 3CA-3CD through their CA login, and the assessee approves it on or before the due date.
deadline.gracePeriod: The Income-tax Act does not provide an automatic grace period beyond the prescribed due date. However, the Central Board of Direct Taxes (CBDT) frequently exercises its administrative powers to extend due dates for tax audit reports for specific years via circulars and press releases, effectively acting as a one-time grace extension for that year.
deadline.extensions: For FY 2024-25 (AY 2025-26), several extensions are reflected in 2025 sources: (1) Base statutory due date: 30 September 2025, as per the general FAQs on Tax Audit on incometaxindia.gov.in and articles such as Economic Times (20 Sept 2025) and Legalwiz (30 Aug 2025) which refer to 30 September 2025 as the normal tax audit deadline. (2) First extension to 31 October 2025: The Income Tax Department’s 'News & e-Campaigns' page (official portal) specifically notes that the due date for filing of audit report has been extended from 30 September 2025 to 31 October 2025 in the case of assessees referred in clause (a) of the relevant provision (i.e., audit cases under section 139(1)). This is echoed in the AcumenGroup article 'Income Tax Audit Report Due Date Extended FY 2024-25', which states that the new deadline was originally 30 September 2025 but, in the latest CBDT Circular No. 14/2025, it became 31 October 2025. ClearTax’s 'Comprehensive Analysis of Tax Audit: Forms 3CA, 3CB, 3CD, 3CE' also notes that a taxpayer has to obtain the audit report on or before 31 October 2025 for FY 2024-25 (consistent with this first extension). (3) CBDT Circular No. 14/2025: The official Circular No. 14/2025 dated 25 September 2025 (available as a PDF on incometaxindia.gov.in) is titled 'Extension of timelines for filing of various reports of audit for Financial Year 2024-25 (relevant to Assessment Year 2025-26)' and formalises extensions for various audit reports for FY 2024-25; based on secondary summaries (AcumenGroup, ClearTax), it initially extended the due date to 31 October 2025. (4) Further extension to 10 November 2025: ClearTax’s dedicated section 44AB article dated 30 October 2025 explicitly states that the due date for submitting the tax audit report is further extended to 10 November 2025 for FY 2024-25. TaxGuru’s article of 31 October 2025, 'CBDT Extends Tax Audit & ITR Deadlines for AY 2025–26', confirms that 'CBDT extends Tax Audit Report deadline to Nov 10, 2025, and ITR for non-TP audit cases to Dec 10, 2025; TP cases must file ITR by Nov 30.' Thus, the effective final due date for filing Form 3CA-3CD for FY 2024-25 (AY 2025-26) is 10 November 2025. (5) Media and private guidance sites (Times of India, Bajaj Finserv, Economic Times) reported intermediate positions – e.g., Times of India (26 Sept 2025) and Bajaj Finserv (late October 2025) discussed 31 October 2025 as the audit deadline – but these were superseded by the later CBDT extension to 10 November 2025. The PDICAI news item that 'the deadline remains unchanged – September 30, 2025' reflects the situation before extensions.

forms.penalty: Failure to get books audited and/or furnish the tax audit report in Form 3CA-3CD on or before the prescribed/extended due date attracts penalty under section 271B of the Income-tax Act, as consistently described in multiple 2025 guidance sources (Bajaj Finserv, Legalwiz, eBizFiling, Fortune India, PKC India and the analysis of Clause 446 of the Income Tax Bill, 2025). The core penalty structure is: (1) Quantum: Penalty is equal to the lower of (a) 0.5% (one-half per cent) of the total sales, turnover or gross receipts of the business or profession in the relevant previous year; or (b) ₹150,000 (₹1.5 lakh). Bajaj Finserv’s 'Income Tax Audit Under Section 44AB' article states that 'Non-compliance may result in a penalty of 0.5% of turnover (max Rs. 1.5 lakh)' and eBizFiling’s 'Tax Audit for Private Limited Companies 2025' article states that 'A penalty of 0.5% of turnover or ₹1,50,000 (whichever is lower) may be levied under Section 271B.' The Taxtmi note on Clause 446 vs Section 271B likewise notes that non-compliance penalties are substantial but capped at ₹1,50,000. Fortune India’s article on consequences of missing the tax audit filing deadline explains that penalty under section 271B is 0.5% of turnover/gross receipts. (2) Minimum penalty: The law does not prescribe a separate flat minimum monetary penalty; theoretically, the penalty is 0 if the assessee successfully invokes section 273B (reasonable cause) and the tax authority chooses not to levy any penalty. Where levied, the practical minimum is 0.5% of turnover/gross receipts, subject to the ₹150,000 cap (for very small turnovers, 0.5% of turnover can be much lower than ₹150,000). (3) Per-day late fee and interest: Section 271B does not stipulate a per-day late fee or interest rate specifically for late filing of Form 3CA-3CD. The penalty is a one-time computation based on turnover/gross receipts and is independent of the number of days of delay. However, late or non-filing of the associated income tax return may attract separate late fees under section 234F and interest under sections 234A, 234B and 234C, but those are not tax-audit-specific and are not detailed in the provided search results. (4) Reasonable cause defence: Although not elaborated in the snippets, standard law (and referenced in commentary like eBizFiling’s 'Relief is ...' remark) provides that no penalty shall be imposed under section 271B if the assessee proves that there was reasonable cause for failure (section 273B). (5) Additional company law penalties: PKC India’s analysis of penalties for non-compliance with statutory audit notes that, separate from Income-tax Act penalties, the Companies Act can levy fines ranging from around ₹25,000 to ₹500,000 for failures related to statutory audit. Thus, for companies, non-compliance can simultaneously expose them to (a) tax audit penalty of up to 0.5% of turnover capped at ₹150,000, and (b) Companies Act fines for statutory audit defaults. (6) Future codification: The Taxtmi article on Clause 446 of the Income Tax Bill, 2025 suggests that the proposed new Income Tax Bill retains a similar penalty framework, with penalties significant for large businesses but capped at ₹150,000, mirroring the current section 271B regime.

forms.name: Form 3CB with Form 3CD (Tax Audit Report for assessees not required to be audited under any other law)
forms.description: Form 3CB is the audit report format prescribed under section 44AB read with Rule 6G(1)(b) for assessees whose accounts are not otherwise required to be audited under any other law. It is used primarily by non-corporate businesses and professionals such as individuals, HUFs, partnership firms and entities that do not fall under Companies Act or other statutory audit regimes but whose turnover/gross receipts cross section 44AB thresholds. The CA conducts an audit specifically for income-tax purposes and reports findings in Form 3CB. Form 3CD, the detailed statement of particulars, is again furnished along with Form 3CB and contains extensive clause-wise disclosures of tax-relevant information. The PDICAI news item notes that, in the latest income tax audit utility, there are 36 reporting items for the Form 3CB–3CD combination (compared with 35 items for 3CA–3CD), reflecting one additional reporting requirement when there is no separate statutory audit report to rely on. Like Form 3CA-3CD, the Form 3CB-3CD report is filed electronically by a CA via the Income Tax e-Filing portal and then approved by the assessee.

deadline.formula: Same as for Form 3CA-3CD: 30 September of the assessment year following the relevant financial year is the statutory due date for obtaining and filing the tax audit report in Form 3CB-3CD, subject to any year-specific extensions notified by CBDT.
deadline.calculation: Identify the financial year (e.g., FY 2024-25) and derive the corresponding assessment year (AY 2025-26). Under the 'FAQs on Tax Audit' on incometaxindia.gov.in, a person covered by section 44AB should get accounts audited and obtain the audit report on or before 30 September of the relevant assessment year. Therefore, for FY 2024-25, the base due date is 30 September 2025. The CA must upload Form 3CB-3CD via the CA login on the e-Filing portal, and the assessee must accept it electronically by that date, unless extended.
deadline.gracePeriod: No automatic statutory grace days; any relief comes only via specific CBDT circulars extending the due date.
deadline.extensions: For FY 2024-25 (AY 2025-26), the same extensions that apply to Form 3CA-3CD apply to Form 3CB-3CD. Specifically: (1) Standard statutory due date was 30 September 2025. (2) CBDT, via its 'News & e-Campaigns' page and Circular No. 14/2025 dated 25 September 2025, extended the due date for filing tax audit reports (for assessees covered under clause (a) of section 139(1), which generally includes 44AB audit cases) from 30 September 2025 to 31 October 2025. This 31 October deadline is reported by Times of India (26 Sept 2025) and Bajaj Finserv’s 'Tax Audit Due Date - Latest Extension Date for FY 2024-25' article (which mentions 'Tax Audit Reports (Form 3CA/3CB-3CD): Due October 31'). (3) Subsequently, as per ClearTax’s section 44AB article dated 30 October 2025 ('The due date for submitting tax audit report is further extended to 10th November, 2025 for FY 2024-25') and TaxGuru’s 31 October 2025 article ('CBDT extends Tax Audit Report deadline to Nov 10, 2025 ...'), the final extended due date for FY 2024-25 tax audit reports became 10 November 2025. Thus, for both Form 3CA-3CD and 3CB-3CD for FY 2024-25, the effective ultimate deadline is 10 November 2025.

forms.penalty: The penalty regime for late or non-filing of Form 3CB-3CD is identical to that for Form 3CA-3CD because both are tax audit reports under section 44AB. As summarised by Bajaj Finserv, Legalwiz, eBizFiling, Fortune India and PKC India, and consistent with section 271B: (1) Penalty quantum: Lower of (a) 0.5% of total sales/turnover/gross receipts of the business or profession for the relevant year; or (b) ₹150,000. This 0.5% of turnover/gross receipts ceiling is emphasised in multiple articles. (2) Nature: It is a one-time penalty; there is no statutory per-day late fee for delay in uploading the audit report. The law does not tie the penalty amount to the number of days of delay; it only looks at the fact of non-compliance with the due date. (3) Minimum/maximum: The maximum penalty is ₹150,000. The effective minimum can be nil if the assessee proves 'reasonable cause' under section 273B and the officer chooses not to levy any penalty. Otherwise, the practical minimum (if levied) is 0.5% of the reported turnover/gross receipts for that year if that amount is less than ₹150,000. (4) Other consequences: Although not specified in the tax-audit-specific articles, delayed tax audit may indirectly cause delayed ITR filing, which in turn can attract late filing fee under section 234F and interest under sections 234A/234B/234C; these apply independently of section 271B. (5) Related statutory audit penalties: For entities that also have statutory audit obligations (e.g., private limited companies), PKC India notes that under the Companies Act, penalties for statutory audit non-compliance can range from ₹25,000 to ₹500,000, separate from tax audit penalties.

forms.name: Form 3CD (Statement of particulars required to be furnished under Section 44AB)
forms.description: Form 3CD is a detailed statement of particulars prescribed under Rule 6G, to be furnished along with the tax audit report in Form 3CA or 3CB. Although filed electronically as part of a combined Form 3CA-3CD or 3CB-3CD package, it is a distinct form listing clause-wise disclosures. The PDICAI news item regarding 'Income tax audit forms are now enabled' specifically mentions that there are 35 reporting items in the Form 3CA-3CD combination and 36 in the Form 3CB-3CD combination, indicating the scope and complexity of the particulars required. The Economic Times article on 'Top five changes in income tax audit form 3CD for AY 2025-26' (20 Sept 2025) confirms that Form 3CD has undergone changes for AY 2025-26, implying additional or revised reporting clauses that CAs and SMEs must carefully review. While the snippets do not list those five changes, they signal that the content and number of disclosures in Form 3CD for AY 2025-26 differ from earlier years and require updated compliance. Form 3CD covers, among other matters, details of nature of business/profession, ownership structure, method of accounting, quantitative stock details, depreciation, disallowances under various sections, compliance with TDS/TCS provisions, payments to specified persons, loans and deposits in contravention of sections 269SS/269T, and other specified tax-sensitive disclosures.

deadline.formula: Form 3CD has the same due date as the tax audit report in Form 3CA or 3CB to which it is annexed, i.e., 30 September of the assessment year following the relevant financial year, subject to extensions notified by CBDT.
deadline.calculation: Because Form 3CD is an integral part of the tax audit report package (3CA-3CD or 3CB-3CD), its due date is not computed separately. For FY 2024-25 (AY 2025-26), one first determines the base statutory due date for tax audit reports (30 September 2025), then applies any extensions applicable to audit reports in general. For that year, official and guidance sources show that the due date moved from 30 September 2025 to 31 October 2025 (per CBDT News & e-Campaigns and Circular 14/2025) and ultimately to 10 November 2025 (per ClearTax section 44AB and TaxGuru), so Form 3CD for that FY is effectively due on 10 November 2025.
deadline.gracePeriod: No separate grace period beyond what is granted for the overall tax audit report; any extension or relaxation for the audit report automatically applies to Form 3CD.
deadline.extensions: For FY 2024-25 (AY 2025-26), Form 3CD benefitted from the same sequence of extensions as Forms 3CA/3CB, moving from 30 September 2025 to 31 October 2025 and then to 10 November 2025, as per CBDT Circular 14/2025 and later CBDT notifications summarised by ClearTax and TaxGuru. Economic Times’ article on 'Top five changes in income tax audit form 3CD for AY 2025-26' underscores that, apart from the extended timelines, the content of Form 3CD has been updated, requiring CAs and assessees to use the latest version of the form for AY 2025-26.

forms.penalty: There is no standalone penalty that applies only to Form 3CD separate from the penalty for the tax audit report itself. Failure to furnish correct or complete particulars in Form 3CD, or failure to furnish the form on time, is treated as failure to comply with section 44AB and attracts penalty under section 271B, computed as the lower of 0.5% of turnover/gross receipts or ₹150,000, as explained across Bajaj Finserv, Legalwiz, eBizFiling, Fortune India and PKC India articles. In serious cases involving false statements or misreporting, other penalty or prosecution provisions (e.g., for furnishing inaccurate information) may separately apply under the Income-tax Act, but these are beyond what is detailed in the provided search results. There is no per-day penalty tied specifically to Form 3CD; timing and completeness are enforced via the general section 271B framework and the reasonable-cause relief under section 273B.

forms.name: Form 3CE (other audit/accountant’s report form referenced in tax audit guidance)
forms.description: The ClearTax article titled 'Comprehensive Analysis of Tax Audit: Forms 3CA, 3CB, 3CD, 3CE' lists Form 3CE alongside the main tax audit forms. Form 3CE, within the Income-tax Rules framework, relates to accountant’s reports for specified cross-border or non-resident situations (for example, certain non-resident income streams or royalty/technical fee arrangements) rather than the generic domestic tax audit under section 44AB. It is mentioned in the context of audit-related forms but is not the primary audit report form for standard SME businesses or professions. The snippets do not provide detail on its exact statutory basis or clauses, but its inclusion indicates that some specialised audit/reporting obligations beyond section 44AB may be relevant for SMEs engaged in specified international or non-resident transactions.

deadline.formula: The specific statutory due date formula for Form 3CE is not detailed in the provided search snippets. In practice, timelines for specialised accountant’s reports such as Form 3CE are typically linked to the due date for filing the relevant income tax return under section 139(1) or the specific section under which the report is prescribed.
deadline.calculation: Not explicitly provided in the search results. Assessees who may be required to file Form 3CE (generally in connection with non-resident-related income or specified international tax provisions) need to refer directly to the underlying section and rule in the Income-tax Act/Rules or to the detailed ClearTax article for precise computation of due dates.
deadline.gracePeriod: No information on grace period for Form 3CE is provided in the search results. Any extensions, if granted, would be by specific CBDT notification or circular for that type of report.
deadline.extensions: The provided search results on deadline extensions (CBDT Circular 14/2025 and TaxGuru/ClearTax summaries) refer generally to 'various reports of audit' but do not explicitly list Form 3CE or clarify whether its due date was extended in the same way as section 44AB tax audits. Users potentially subject to Form 3CE obligations should examine Circular 14/2025 in full and any subsequent CBDT instructions or consult a tax professional.

forms.penalty: The search results do not provide a specific penalty structure for Form 3CE. In general, failure to furnish an accountant’s report required under the Income-tax Act can attract penalties under the provision corresponding to that report (not necessarily section 271B) and, depending on the section, may also attract broader penalties for non-compliance or misreporting. Because the snippets only signal the existence of Form 3CE in a list of tax audit-related forms without describing its penalty mechanism, assessees should refer to the underlying statutory provision for Form 3CE to determine exact penalties and any applicable reasonable-cause defenses.
